talk.start.para: —There is no doubt about the old gadfly. He is out there running around talking to everybody under the sun. He today asked the second question since November on industry policy. It is no wonder he is out here with the MPI today, because he knows that tomorrow the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) will want to talk and he knows that Beazley has to have the last day, so he had to get in today. What does he do? He asks the second question since November and gets the MPI. That is a really good start. It shows you the great interest of the plumber. He is not interested in industry policy; he has taken up plumbing. He is down there throwing the dirt around—`Don't worry about industry policy, we will get on to other things.'

speech.para: In the meantime, can I suggest that the Ericsson question be addressed more thoroughly. When I came to the office this morning, there were big headlines saying, `Ericsson's leaves Australia.' I got on to the managing director and said, `Is that true?' He said, `No, it is not.' The industry spokesman got up and said, `They are all off.' I asked him to send up a statement of exactly where he was in relation to this. He said:

Ericsson Australia said today that it had no intention of withdrawing operations from Australia. . . . Australia has been identified as a host for key Ericsson regional centres, such as the Regional Supply Centre, Training and Education Centre, Service Centre, Competence Centre and the Global Design Centre among others. With these initiatives in place, Ericsson Australia will continue to build on the high level competencies available in Australia, strengthening its presence and outlook.

That is no resignation from Australia. It means more jobs in the higher paid sectors. It means more commitment to IT and the research and development we so badly need in this area. So the very premise on which the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) leads off in his gadfly sort of way is wrong. Make the assertion, colour and movement, no fact. Don't worry about the truth of the statement, just assert it. That is the usual sort of thing that he goes on with.

What has the government been doing since we came to office? When we came to office in March 1996, there was no industry policy. It had collapsed. Richardson admitted that. He said it straight out. The member for Hotham said, `Maybe we made a few mistakes.' Even he owned up. It took a while, but even he owned up in the end. So we systematically went about the work we had on hand.

First of all, do you remember the research and development syndicates? That was the member for Hotham's special little area where he fixed up his mates in the Rolls-Royces. We had to clean that area up. In IT there had been no review for ten years, so we moved on that area. In the manufacturing sector, there had been 200,000 jobs lost by Labor. We hear a lot about jobs. In the `recession we had to have', 200,000 jobs were removed from that area by Labor. We had record debt and record interest rates. And don't forget the `recession we had to have' which went with these situations.

Our international competitiveness, which must drive Australia all the time to get to 2010 and meet the open competition that year, in this period fell from 10 to 21. What a record. Labor failed industry in this nation. Graham Richardson attested to that. He said that the greatest single mistake of successive Labor governments from 1983 to 1996 was the failure to develop a cohesive industry policy. When Richardson says that, you have to take notice in the Labor Party.

What did we do? We set about a systematic review of industry in this nation. We called upon David Mortimer to undertake a complete review of all government support across the board. We asked Professor Goldsworthy and Mr Cutler to take a complete review of the IT industries. It was the first strategic review of IT for ten years, as I said before. It is very significant. This is a very big area for Australia and something which we really have to hold on to and develop. So we put those two people onto that task.

In the area of cars, we answered the challenge of the post-2000 period. When the Productivity Commission came forward with their recommendations, the government was driven by its key areas of industry policy: investment, research and development innovation, and exports. Those three things led us in government to make the decision to extend the tariffs to the year 2005 and implement a significant investment program. There has been a significant response to that by the industry itself. Something like $4 billion has been committed to it so far in relation to the auto producers themselves, and the component manufacturers are making enormous developments in these areas, especially with magnesium and the like.

We pressed on to TCF, a very hard area to handle in terms of regions and employment. There we came up with another program, with heavy reliance on investment, research and development, and pushing them into export areas. We are doing something for our future. We answered the question of pharmaceuticals, another area looked at comprehensively by the government in industry policy. In this time, since March 1996, we have covered the whole area of industry policy in this nation. We have had the most comprehensive review of industry policy in 20 years and this has been endorsed not only by members of the manufacturing sector and other areas but also by the very many people who have understood the concepts that we have put behind this in relation to it.

There are a number of initiatives from the statement Investing for Growth, made in December by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), which we have already implemented. The government has moved in terms of research and development, a very significant area. We have started and extended the new START program. We have introduced innovation funds because we in Australia know that one of the missing links has been the development of venture capital. Good ideas and research and development have not been taken up because of the reluctance of the private investor to get involved in the commercialisation of the sector. So we introduced innovation funds, which have been a great success, and five have already been announced and taken up. In relation to extended areas of research and development, we have made it possible to get up to the equivalent of a 200 per cent deduction if you are in the competitive area of research and development.

In terms of investment, Mr Bob Mansfield was appointed as the strategic investment coordinator to assist the government in reviewing various projects that come to hand. Already, we have enabled the Kistler space launching facility at Woomera in South Australia to be established. Wholesale sales tax in relation to that project was reviewed to enable that project to take place. That has been progressed in a number of other areas. We have moved on manufacture in bond and have allotted the first licence in that area. It is a very significant step to be able to bring in manufacture in Australia and re-export those products without incurring government costs in that area. None of these things were done under Labor—or thought of. As I said, this is the most comprehensive review in 20 years.

To promote Australia as a financial centre, we have moved to develop the new Tradex program. Information technology is a special area and was mentioned today by the member for Hotham. In this area, as I said at question time, a ministerial council has been set up, chaired by Senator Alston, which is responsible for a whole of government response to information online service strategies. The government established a National Office of the Online Economy, for which Senator Alston is also responsible. We have announced the removal of tariffs on inputs to IT manufacturing in Australia—a very significant step indeed. The measure is projected to save Australian IT manufacturers more than $80 million over the next 18 months.

The government, as of tomorrow, will be starting up its first action agenda in the information industry sector, at a cost of some $28 million. In particular, it will set up a network of software engineering quality centres and a new testing conformance infrastructure. These are necessary since the withdrawal of Telstra from this field and will enable a wider number of bodies, both small and large, to test new products. So I think the government has responded in a very comprehensive way to a lot of the areas set out in Investing for Growth which was, as I was saying, a very significant statement.

In contrast, what has Labor done? They run around, but I do not know what their policy is. They come out making a wild series of statements, I am fully aware of that. But what really is their policy? They have not got any policy. The member for Hotham has asked only two questions on industry policy since November last year and he comes to the third last day of the winter sittings before he can get an MPI up, so he cannot be too interested in industry policy.

Labor are going to run around with industry and say, `Look, we will do special deals with our mates.' That is one thing the member for Hotham is good at. It is a really hot point. It is in the documents. Labor are saying they will get back to mutual commitment where industry agrees to a precise job in exports and investments and, in return, in government they will help them along. I assume that means that all those who do not go along and cooperate with the government get no assistance. They are saying that if you come to the government, they will give you something but if you do not talk to them, they will give you nothing. So in government they would divide everyone up. The Labor mates would get a few bob and the others are to be forgotten about. This is the new-found industry policy of the Labor Party. It is back to the bad old days down at the ACTU and the New South Wales Right, hand in the pocket. They have been at that for years. There is nothing new about this. This is the greatest mob of failed politicians I have seen in all my life.

Those opposite ask us to go and look at the past. Business expenditure under Labor on R&D as a share of GDP was 25 per cent lower than the OECD average. Under Labor, Australia slipped from 18th to 24th in terms of business expenditure on R&D. It is no wonder they run around and talk about these terrible things. Labor's foreign investment policy promised to promote Australia as an attractive and highly competitive destination for investment, said Senator Cook in San Francisco. Labor's business investment averaged under five per cent per year. Under the coalition, business investment has grown by more than 17 per cent since March 1996. The CSIRO is one of Australia's great scientific institutions. Labor promised to cut $60 million from Australian funding in 1995-96. The coalition moved to restore that, and I am very pleased that happened.

In terms of international competitiveness, under Labor Australia fell from 10th to 21st position in the Institute of Management Development ranking of international competitiveness. In only two years the coalition had turned Australia's competitiveness around, improving six places to 15th place in the IMD's world ranking. Inflation under Labor averaged 5.5 per cent between March 1983 and March 1986. Inflation now is at the lowest sustained levels ever recorded—below one per cent.

Turning to overdraft rates—and who in business does not understand the importance of interest rates and the cost of money in this nation?—under Labor, business overdraft rates reached 20.8 per cent in 1990, and you probably would have paid a lot more than that in the fringe market. Under the coalition, bank overdraft rates are now 7½ per cent, having fallen 3½ per cent in two years. The government's net debt is just under 20 per cent of GDP in 1995-96. Based on current projections and including the Telstra sale and receipts, Commonwealth general government net debt will decline to around 1½ per cent of GDP by the year 2000-01.

Unemployment under Labor averaged 8.7 per cent. Presently it is averaging 8.1 per cent. The Labor recession caused the worst unemployment in 60 years—an unemployment rate of 11.2 per cent with youth unemployment over 26 per cent. Turning to manufacturing unemployment—and we hear this from the opposition—under Labor, some 200,000 jobs went despite the fact that it is one of Australia's largest areas of employment. It was unable to make the slightest positive contribution to economic growth in 1995.

When Labor were getting towards the end and they were running around looking for something to do, they decided to have a brand new industry statement—Innovate Australia. They could not agree on it, so in the end the department had to cobble together a series of press statements. It was really a great event. When it came out with all the bluster and hoo-ha that went with it, what happened? In the innovation statement, the total outlays over four years were going to be $465 million. But what did they charge and raise from industry in the same statement? Some $818 million. The opposition talk about who has given the most to industry, who has given the most support to industry, who is backing them up and doing the right thing? In your last effort at it, you gave them $400 million and you took back $800 million. With Invest Australia, we put out $1.4 billion and you have never matched it.

talk.start.para: —When are you going to start making an effort?
—You can say all the things you like. The great gadfly from Hotham has no policy and no action. (Time expired)

—After that rambling, incomprehensible speech by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), we on this side of the House really rest our case. Just have a look at your own back bench. If it is a case of `Oh, lonesome me' defending the government's industry policy, then you are it. The minister claims in this debate that he has conducted the most comprehensive review of industry policy in 20 years. Minister, where are the results of this great industry review and your performance? I will tell you what they are: low economic growth, high unemployment, low job growth, jobs lost by the thousand in manufacturing—and you and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) still persist with the fantasy that you have fireproofed the Australian economy from the Asian economic firestorm.

speech.para: This Howard government is the worst government in Australia's history. After winning a substantial majority when it was elected in 1996, John Howard and Peter Costello have squandered their accumulated political capital in a manner which has left the Liberal backbench sullen and angry, and the electorate bitter and disappointed. In 27 months in office this has been a government of dishonesty, a government of betrayal, a government of incompetence and a government lacking leadership of substance. In no other policy area has this dishonesty, this betrayal, this incompetence and this lack of leadership been more manifest than in the area of industry policy. Australia's great manufacturing industries are reeling from Asia's economic turmoil. But if that were not enough, they have to contend with a government which is in an advanced state of panic and decay and incapable of developing and implementing a coherent industry policy to guide the national economy through these very troubled times.

What manufacturing industry wanted from this government was stability. What it got was seven resignations in 27 months. That is almost one in every four months. This government has not even been able to go a footy season without a resignation. What manufacturing industry wanted was ministerial competence. The government got John Moore, who should have been sacked for his own breaches of ministerial conduct. What manufacturing industry wanted was that the promises that were made would be promises that would be kept. But in shipbuilding, printing, automotive, textiles, clothing and footwear, and research and development all it got was broken promises. What manufacturing industry wanted was a federal government that was able to articulate a vision for Australian manufacturing in the new millennium. What it got was a government that has ripped the heart out of research and development and massively cut expenditure on education and training, the pillars on which Australia's future prosperity will be built.

The electorate of Corio, which I represent in this parliament, has a very strong manufacturing base. Its key manufacturing industries are automotive and component manufacture, and textiles, clothing and footwear manufacture. In both of these areas we have seen a comprehensive betrayal by this minister and by this government. On 5 June 1997, the Prime Minister and the minister announced the government's decision in relation to the automotive industry.

talk.start.para: —More than 12 months ago.

—Twelve months ago the minister announced the government's decision with regard to this very critical industry to Australia and my electorate. You adopted major elements of our industry plan, and some of what you announced we did not agree with. But there is no certainty as far as this industry is concerned because 12 months down the line you have done nothing to introduce into this House the legislation that gives effect to the industry plan that you announced over one year ago. That is a betrayal of the workers in Geelong and the automotive workers throughout Australia and a betrayal of the regions that rely on this great industry.

speech.para: The government made its announcement in relation to the TCF industries in September 1997. The government has taken no legislative action on the commitments that it made to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries of this nation at that time. This represents another betrayal of the 3,000 workers in my electorate who depend on this industry for their livelihood and the great regions of Australia in which this particular industry is situated. If we go to the printing industry, that is only a little betrayal because the government made its commitment six months ago and has done nothing about it.

It is not only in the broad industry policy areas that this government has been found wanting. In very specific areas of policy that require some intellectual analysis and a sophisticated response this government has demonstrated its capacity not to grasp the complexities of policy or understand the implications of what it intends to do. One such area has already been mentioned today in debate in this House—the proposed amendments to the Copyright Amendment Bill 1997 . In particular, schedule 3 removes the safeguards currently available to Australian copyright holders and allows parallel imports of goods where there is copyright on accessories such as packaging and labelling. What the government is proposing has the potential to create widespread unemployment in a range of industries, including the food and beverages, apparel, footwear and fashion accessories industries. These problems are symptomatic of the government's whole industry policy approach: failure to understand the implications of what they are doing and failure to consult with key industry stakeholders on issues that affect them.

The government's industry policy failure is evidenced by the collapse of manufacturing jobs over the past two years. The Prime Minister promised to create 200,000 new manufacturing jobs by the year 2000. The record shows that, in the 27 months since the election, there has been a loss in manufacturing jobs in this country. Indeed, last year 32,900 manufacturing workers lost their jobs. The true situation for industry in Australia is contained in the budget. Net export growth will drop, business investment growth will slow and demand for research and development funds from the government is at an all-time low. The budget does not allocate one cent to the textiles, clothing and footwear package. We have seen a decline in support for manufacturing industry, we have seen a collapse in assistance for the information technology industries in this country and we have seen the virtual abolition of AusIndustry support for enterprise development.

Of course, this contrasts with Labor's success in office. Those elements have already been outlined by the member for Hot ham (Mr Crean), but I will quote a few here. Under Labor, we saw manufacturing reach record growth with a 12.2 per cent increase in production in 1994 alone. In plans for sectors such as the motor vehicle industry, we saw exports climb from less than $400 million in 1984 to $1.5 billion in 1994. We saw support for science and technology increased to $3.2 billion a year.

This government has comprehensively failed in one of the most critical areas of public policy today. This government's policy is being administered by a minister who does not deserve the portfolio. In the hallowed halls of industry across the length and breadth of this country the minister is a joke and so is his government. Australian industry will not be placed in a very good position beyond the year 2000 if the policies and the lack of direction that we currently face continue to be pursued. There is one simple solution to this: that we cut the Liberal-National Party cancer out of the body politic in Australia. The sooner the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) calls the election, the sooner Australian industry will have a real government in this country that will address its longstanding needs for a policy direction of substance. It will get that when this electorate elects a Labor government.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to be participating in this matter of public importance debate. Correct if I am wrong—perhaps I am misreading their mood—but it seems to me that the opposition do not have their hearts in this matter of public importance, as evidenced by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor). They came in and they read their speeches. Their passion for industry, their outrage, is so significant that they came in with some speeches written by their staff. They made a number of assertions and trotted out some old cliches.

speech.para: Does the opposition know why this MPI cannot be taken seriously? There are a number of reasons, but this is the main reason: if the government's industry policy has been so calamitous over the last 2½ years, as they allege; if industry is besieged; and if there has been a collapse of 200,000 jobs, as alleged by the member for Corio, why haven't the opposition done something about it before now? Why is the industry question asked today only the second industry question in the last eight months? Why is this the only MPI on industry that we have had for some 12 months? If things are as bad as the opposition make out, why haven't they been performing their responsibility as an opposition and drawing the situation to the attention of the House? It is simply because the government has cut the ground completely and utterly from underneath them.

The government has performed extremely well in all the complex and often interrelated issues of industry policy since coming to office. Finally, to put the opposition's baying to rest once and for all, the government released late last year `Investing for growth'—the most complete, creditable industry policy released by any government for several decades. So the hype, the exaggeration and the overstatement of their case that we have seen here today have fallen very flat. That is what you would expect from the Labor Party.

Any industry policy debate should be kicked off with the words of former Senator Graham Richardson, a cabinet minister in both the Hawke and Keating governments, which appeared in the Bulletin on 17 June last year. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) has already briefly referred to the article. Former Senator Richardson said:
The greatest mistake of successive Labor governments from 1983 to 1996 was the failure to develop a coherent industry policy.

But just in case anybody should think Senator Richardson was on an adventure of his own, and settling some old scores—heaven forbid—he was corroborated by the shadow minister for industry, the member for Hotham, Simon Crean, on Radio National on 11 August last year when he confessed:
I think we have to admit we did not get it all right.

They certainly did not get any of it right. You only have to look at their performance over 13 years to see the disastrous consequences of their industry policies such as they were. And they are still at it! That is the amazing thing. Does Labor ever learn anything?

We saw the release of their platform policy in January at the Labor Party conference and recently the draft industry development plan of the member for Hotham. What you have got to remember about this 1½-page effort is that it is just a reworking of Labor's track record in government; that is, they will intervene very selectively, according to what suits their political interests more than anything else, in certain sectors and abandon others. One of the most amazing things is that Labor tried to dress this up with some form of respectability by saying:
. . . Labor believes that industry policy measures must be developed and implemented on the basis of a shared responsibility.
That is a nice motherhood introduction. It continues:

Assistance provided to industries will therefore be on the basis of a firm commitment between government and industry—a mutual commitment whereby industry agrees to specific job, export and investment targets in exchange for government providing the best possible environment to achieve those targets.

The best possible environment! It is a party that gave us record inflation and record unemployment, record interest rates, that plunged the economy into the worst recession since the Great Depression of the early 1930s. But, even if we were to allow them a fresh start, they are condemned by their own modern words, for what does it mean: will require `specific job, export and investment targets'? Spell it out. What are the criteria? What is the measurement? What is the enforcement? What is the penalty? None of this, in either the platform or the subsequent industry development plan, is announced for us to judge.

What happens if they give assistance on the basis of targets being satisfied and those targets are not met? Is the money withdrawn? What if certain industries cannot meet those targets? Do they miss out? Even Labor's car and steel plans would have failed these tests. They would not have met any test for re-investment, for jobs, for targets or for export benchmarks, because both those plans saw a loss of jobs in those industries across the life of the plan.

These are hollow statements. They do not add up. They are pandering to a sectoral part of the community all right, and that is the trade union movement more than anything else. There are no clear details. We do not know what they mean. The Labor Party will not expand on these broadest of policy statements. We do not know how much they will cost. We do not know what paperwork and red tape they will require. And we certainly do not know what they will really do for industry.
But it is not just us asking these questions and making these condemnations. Alan Mitchell, in the Financial Review of 21 January this year, said:
It is difficult to imagine a clearer . . . example in Australia of the failure of intellectual and political leadership.
Ross Gittins, in the Sydney Morning Herald on 16 June 1997:
It takes no expertise, no thought, no courage—and no integrity—to lurch back to the policies of the `60's, and that's the best Kim can come up with.

Meanwhile, his rival, Simon Crean, has something new and exciting: "industry policy"—which means lots of "plans" and Budget subsidies, with Simon doing all the deals with his Melbourne manufacturing mates.
Apparently this is something we've never tried before.
The Age editorial of 24 November last year, headed `Labor looks to the past for its future', said the platform:

. . . relies on broad statements of social-democratic principle, rather than detailed policies of the kind laid down in the existing platform. This means that it remains unclear just where the Labor party is headed . . .

And the list goes on and on. Max Walsh, in the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 November 1996, said that `Simon Crean's interventionism is simply a re-packaging' of the historically documented problems of protectionism and it will be a `costly mistake'. There is page after page of ridicule and condemnation of the member for Hotham, in particular, but also the Labor Party that is endorsing his ad hoc, ill-defined and generalised industry intervention policies.

In place of Labor's confusion and uncertainties, and outright superficialities, you have the government's industry policy. I wonder whether or not the opposition has bothered to read the `Investing for growth' document of the government. There you will see every aspect of industry policy comprehensively brought together, as well as an array of government financial assistance and incentives.

Quite frankly, Labor has nothing to tell the government about industry policy because the major initiatives for the government's policy of investing for growth include provision of over $1 billion for four years for targeted support for innovation. We more proactively promote Australia's advantages as an investment location through the Invest Australia program. We have specific incentives to attract strategic investment projects to Australia. We expanded the export market development grants scheme. We introduced a new system, as the minister referred to earlier on, of manufacture in bond. We introduced a range of taxation measures to increase the attractiveness of Australia as a financial centre, providing $80 million over four years. As well as that we have a 125 per cent tax incentive for R&D, and we have got a range of programs which provide for targeted support for basic R&D, commercialisation and technology diffusion.

The government's policy, whether microeconomically directed or by macroeconomic settings, is to make sure Australia's economy is strong, is competitive, is export orientated and is able to meet the challenges of a greater and greater free trade. The Labor Party have put together a gladbag of ideas, mostly drawn from the wish list of their union or manufacturing mates. It serves only a small sector of their constituency and not Australian industry as a whole. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the third, fourth and fifth reports of the committee for 1998 relating to the East Coast Armament Complex, Point Wilson, Victoria, development of the Eastern Region Operations Centre at RAAF Base Williamtown, New South Wales and redevelopment of facilities at RAAF Base Amberley, Queensland.

speech.para: Ordered that the reports be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I thank the House. The first report which I have tabled concerns the proposed construction of an east coast armament complex at Point Wilson, Victoria. This proposal involves the construction of a facility at Point Wilson to support ammunitioning and deammunitioning of the navy's warships and for a Defence import facility for explosive ordnance.

speech.para: The extent of the proposal involved explosive and non-explosive storehouses, a transit facility, container parking and truck holding bays, an administration centre, a workshop security checkpoint, an isolation facility, engineering services and civil works. In addition, the existing jetty, which is nearly two kilometres long, and wharf amenities were proposed for refurbishment. When referred to the committee, the estimated outturn cost of the proposal was $72.27 million. The committee has recommended that the proposal not proceed as proposed.

The report traces the history of this proposal, which has its origins in the need to close what Defence have called the Sydney ammunition pipeline. This involves transporting ordnance by truck and by barge from the ordnance storage facilities in western Sydney to the fleet base at Garden Island. The committee recognised the need for this practice to cease. At present, the importation of explosive ordnance takes place through Point Wilson. It was submitted that Point Wilson was the only site that could provide both a deammunitioning facility and a 1,000 tonne net explosives quantity container import facility.

In terms of the navy's operational requirements, the committee found that Point Wilson was highly unsatisfactory due to: the distance from the fleet base in Sydney Harbour and the navy's exercise area off Jervis Bay; the depth of water available for its largest ship, which would not allow berthing when fully loaded; and the lengthy road journey to Kingswood in western Sydney and return to allow for servicing of unloaded weaponry. The reality was that ships would travel all the way from Sydney to Port Philip Bay where they would have 30 tonnes of ammunition unloaded. They would then travel all the way back to Sydney for repairs. During that period, a trucking exercise would take the ordnance back up to western Sydney for service and maintenance, and then all of those processes would be repeated.

The committee also found that berthing facilities at Point Wilson require extensive upgrading to provide a long-term loading and unloading capability for the importation of explosive ordnance and the ammunitioning and deammunitioning of naval vessels. It would also require the purchase of expensive land for further buffer purposes. These disadvantages were considered acceptable to the Department of Defence on the understanding that no suitable 1,000 tonne net explosive quantity facility existed elsewhere. However, inquiries by the committee have established that such a licensed facility—Port Alma, the port for Rockhampton in Queensland—exists already. In fact, most consignments of Defence ordnance, transported on specialised chartered container ships, berth at Port Alma to unload other portions of their cargo—mainly for commercial reasons—before proceeding to Point Wilson. Port Alma is fully licensed for a 1,500 tonne net explosive quantity, and is serviced within 20 kilometres by a state government explosives magazine.

The committee recognised that Port Alma would impose an additional distance for land transportation back to storage facilities in western Sydney. However, this is offset by reduced sea transport to Point Wilson and the fact that very small quantities of containers—approximately 100 per annum—are involved. A slight increase in freight costs easily outweighs the $24.757 million required to upgrade Point Wilson to provide a long-term import facility.

Based on these factors, once the need for a dual facility is discounted, and because the navy requirement for deammunitioning is approximately 30 tonnes net explosive quantity, the committee concluded that numerous deepwater facilities closer to Sydney, capable of meeting this criterion, are available and should be investigated. One such location is Twofold Bay—the bay upon which the town of Eden is established—which offers excellent low-cost or free land for onshore facilities and buffer zones both for the current proposal and for future expansion. In this regard, were these matters to proceed, there is a very significant role for the New South Wales government in speedily providing what is forest land, of which very small portions are needed for the actual facilities but large areas that are untouched would become a buffer zone.

We have interviewed officials of the New South Wales government. We sincerely hope that they will be forthcoming in encouraging this facility to be established in the state of New South Wales. The committee therefore has recommended that the Department of Defence should re-examine the works in this reference and undertake further investigations into alternatives covered in the report, with a view to referring the revised proposal for an armament complex to the committee at a later but, I hope, early date.

The second report which I have tabled involves the proposed development of the Eastern Region Operations Centre at RAAF Base Williamtown, New South Wales. In brief, this involves a proposal for the construction of a new facility at RAAF Base Williamtown to enable the No. 41 Wing Headquarters and No. 3 Control and Reporting Unit to be collocated and integrated. When referred to the committee, the estimated out turn cost of the proposal was $18 million.

The committee has recommended that this proposal should proceed. The committee has concluded that there is a need to provide facilities for No. 41 Wing and its subordinate units to improve their operational effectiveness. A purpose designed Sector Operations Centre at RAAF Base Williamtown would be available to back up the one in Northern Australia, in keeping with the accepted concept of a layered air defence system. Construction of a new facility would ensure compatibility with new equipment being acquired, and the new facility would be purpose built to suit contemporary operational needs.

The remaining conclusions address savings which would stem from the proposal in addition to enhanced operational effectiveness. The report also recommends the need for urgent Commonwealth, state and local government action to address the question of responsibilities for flood mitigation measures and to combine forces to undertake the necessary measures.

The third report which I have tabled concerns the proposed redevelopment of facilities at RAAF Base Amberley. When referred to the committee, the estimated out turn cost of the proposed work was $73.7 million. The committee has recommended that the project should proceed as proposed.

As one of the RAAF's major air bases, RAAF Base Amberley is the home base of the RAAF's Strike Reconnaissance Group and supports a variety of other air force units. Despite investment and new facilities which have been made over the past three decades, many of the existing base facilities are over 50-years-old. Some buildings used for the support of F111 aircraft are converted buildings which were constructed during the Second World War. An examination of the future direction of the base, undertaken by the Department of Defence, identified deficiencies which adversely affect the ability of the base to perform its designated roles in a safe and flexible manner.

The committee therefore has concluded that a need exists to redevelop or provide new facilities at RAAF Base Amberley to enhance operational training, aircraft maintenance, logistics, and domestic and ancillary capabilities. The scope of the proposed works can be justified as addressing shortcomings in the existing facilities and infrastructure that have contributed to inefficient work practices and reduced productivity levels. The new work will contribute to increased compliance with modern health and safety standards.

A number of heritage buildings are proposed to be demolished to make way for new facilities or because they will no longer be required when the project is completed. Arising from concerns expressed by a number of heritage organisations, the committee therefore has recommended that the Department of Defence should consult further with heritage authorities before demolishing these buildings.

Similarly, because a number of highly toxic substances are used in the maintenance of F111 aircraft, the committee has recommended that, as part of the project, the Department of Defence should undertake a detailed study of liquid trade waste generation—its storage, treatment and disposal—to eliminate any risk of toxic substances entering waterways adjacent to the base or entering the watertable. I commend these reports to the House.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I present the following report: Report No. 362—General and specific purpose payments to states .

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The Australian states and territories are dependent on funding from the Commonwealth for a significant proportion of their expenditure. The financial assistance provided by the Commonwealth to state and local governments is a substantial component of both the outlays of the Commonwealth and the revenues of the other levels of government. It accounted for approximately 20 per cent of the total outlays of the Commonwealth general government sector in 1996-97. It also represented approximately 37 per cent of the total revenues of the state general government sector, and 19 per cent of that of the local general government sector.

speech.para: All Commonwealth payments to the states and territories are made as specific purpose payments or general purpose payments. The grants are contingent upon the fulfilment of a wide range of terms and conditions. The conditions which the Commonwealth usually attaches to the use of SPP funds are generally set out in Commonwealth legislation, in agreements concluded between the parties, or in other program documentation. While conditions are not imposed on the states' use of GPPs, some conditions are attached to the receipt of those funds. These conditions are set out in states grants general purposes legislation.

The JCPAA was asked by the Senate to report on conditions which may appropriately be attached to both SPPs and GPPs. From its examination of SPP program administrative arrangements, the committee reached a number of conclusions regarding SPP payments and conditions which may appropriately be attached to them.

In particular, the committee believes that Commonwealth departments should draw upon the ideal features, which it has set out in this report, in preparing specific conditions to be attached to individual SPPs under their administration. For example, the committee believes that, for efficient and effective management of SPP programs, it is important that SPP program objectives are specified in terms of clear, achievable and measurable outcomes; that the roles of the parties to SPP arrangements and their responsibilities for particular program management activities are clearly defined; and that SPP financial accountability requirements are as streamlined as possible.

I turn now to general purpose payments. The committee examined the four payment conditions which the states are currently required to meet for receipt of GPP funds. The most significant of the four conditions requires the states to comply with obligations relating to the implementation of national competition policy and related industry reform. The Commonwealth will make payments totalling some $16 billion over nine years to the states if they make satisfactory progress in implementing the reforms.

The case of national competition payments indicates that conditional GPP funding can advance broader agreed reform agendas under particular circumstances. This suggests to the committee that there is potential for greater conditional GPP funding in the future, particularly where there is shared Commonwealth and state commitment to regulatory reform, where there are demonstrable economic or other benefits to the Australian people in the national economy and where agreed funding conditions satisfactorily address the particular interests of the Commonwealth and the states.

Other GPP payment conditions require the states to make payments to the Commonwealth in the form of fiscal contributions and higher education superannuation contributions. The states are also required to make payments for any Commonwealth grants to higher education student organisations as a consequence of state actions preventing or hindering the collection of student organisation fees. Each of these conditions was enacted to deal with special circumstances, and it is not likely to have more general application to GPP funding in the future. The committee therefore concluded that there is little to be gained from attempting to prescribe a definite list of specific conditions which might appropriately be applied to hypothetical future conditional GPP funding arrangements. These conditions would need to be determined for each case.

The report also addresses conditions relating to the role of state auditors-general. The committee found that problems have been encountered by state auditors-general when financial audit and acquittal responsibilities are imposed on them under SPP arrangements between the Commonwealth and the states. The committee believes that, in the interests of enhancing the public accountability of Commonwealth and state government agencies for specific purpose payments programs, without compromising the statutory independence of state auditors-general, it is important that responsibilities for the financial certification of SPP payments are not imposed on state auditors-general. It is important that opportunities for the conduct of coordinated or joint audits of SPP programs by Commonwealth and state auditors-general continue to be actively pursued.

The JCPAA was also asked to inquire into `recent developments concerning the Victorian Auditor-General'. Although the committee found this part of the terms of reference to be imprecise, the committee has taken it to allude to the review of the Victorian Audit Act 1994, which was initiated by the Victorian government in 1996. In the committee's view, this is a matter which falls within the constitutional jurisdiction of the state of Victoria. The JCPAA's mandate is limited to the Commonwealth sphere.

This committee, like its predecessor, the JCPA, has been very mindful of its duties and responsibilities as set out under the act. The JCPA, in inquiring into the administration of specific purpose payments in 1994 and 1995, did not comment on the administrative practices of the non-Commonwealth parties to SPP agreements. Accordingly, the JCPAA has not addressed the issue of `recent developments concerning the Victorian Auditor-General' in this report. This report has drawn attention to the range of conditions attached to general purpose and specific purpose payments and identified ideal features of these conditions. It has highlighted the significant and special place of the auditors-general in the overall accountability framework for the administration of these payments. Finally, constitutionally the Commonwealth may grant financial assistance to the states and territories on such terms and conditions as the parliament sees fit. It is the parliament which is ultimately both the arbiter of the conditions attached to general and specific purpose payments and the institution to which government agencies are accountable for the administration of those payments.

In conclusion, I wish to thank the secretariat staff who have assisted in the production of this report: Gillian Gould; Laura Gillies; in particular, Russell Lapthorne, from the Australian National Audit Office; and the secretary to the committee, Margot Kerley. I also thank my colleagues on the committee for their arduous effort in bringing down this unanimous report. Before I conclude my remarks, I must say that the remarks made earlier by the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) were particularly inappropriate since the member for La Trobe clearly intends to return to parliament after the next election.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I too hope to return after the next election.
—No doubt about it.

—We will wait and see. Elections are funny things. I wish to speak on this particular report. As the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), the Chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, has said, it is a unanimous report and it is quite a lengthy report. I would like to focus on just a couple of aspects of it. As he said, the issue of the terms of reference was one which the committee had to grapple with, particularly with respect to the last section which reads:

speech.para: . . . including conditions relating to the role of State Auditors-General, with particular reference to recent developments concerning the Victorian Auditor-General.

The JCPAA prides itself on always working to the unanimous position as much as possible with respect to its findings. There are some times when that is easier than others, and I guess I would say this is one of those times where there was some difficulty. The nature of that difficulty concerns the question of what we took that particular section of the terms of reference to mean. It did produce some difficulties for the committee. We have certainly taken it to mean that it alludes to the review of the Victorian Audit Act by the Victorian government.

That, as I think members know, has been an issue of considerable controversy in the state of Victoria since it was announced and during its conduct and its findings being acted upon by the government of Victoria. It was one of the reasons given by the then member for Mitcham for his resignation, and it is certainly something which has caused a considerable furore amongst the Victorian public because of concerns about what it does to the actions of the Victorian Auditor-General and his ability to actually conduct the duties of his role and position in an independent manner.

However, the JCPAA basically came to the conclusion that, in the circumstances, given some of the issues which the chairman mentioned, it was impossible for us to properly conduct an inquiry into that aspect of the reference. We, therefore, took the view that it was best to mention some of the problems with that aspect of the reference but otherwise avoid endeavouring to deal with it. It is quite true that we have not had the capacity, or that we believed we would have the capacity, to be able to conduct hearings and seek evidence on that particular issue. We certainly had legal advice to the effect and, as was mentioned by the chairman, the member for La Trobe, there are some constitutional issues. There is also the fact that, previously, when a response, a written submission, was sought by the Senate Victorian Casino Inquiry Select Committee from the Premier of Victoria, he responded:
. . . the State of Victoria is protected by its executive privilege against actions of the Commonwealth which threaten its autonomy or curtail its capacity to function effectively.

. . . the State of Victoria will assert its executive privilege if the Committee attempts to obtain evidence from current or former Ministers or Public Servants, either voluntarily or by compulsion of law.

I think it is fair to say that it was the view of the committee that this would almost certainly be an issue on which the Victorian government would seek to avoid the question of Commonwealth scrutiny. That is their right, and I do not question the fact that they do have that right, but I do think there are some issues around what occurred in respect of the Audit Act in Victoria. That is something that does require some wider scrutiny, but I also accept that, in the circumstances, the situation is that a federal committee such as ours is not, in fact, able to do so. But I do think that it is an issue which, in terms of the Victorian public and in the operation of good practice amongst auditors across this country, needs to be reviewed on an ongoing basis.

I certainly hope that the Victorian government will see the sense of that and actually review the operation of their act over the next couple of years. I think there are some really significant issues about the operation of audit powers within the Victorian jurisdiction, and there are real concerns about what, in fact, is occurring in Victoria under the Kennett government when it comes to the question of the Audit Act.

I congratulate members of the committee and the secretariat for dealing with the difficult task of working out a way to avoid a brawl on the terms of reference. We worked together to achieve that. I certainly do not think there is anything in this report that really deals with that issue; that is probably the way it had to be in the circumstances and, constitutionally, it was the way it had to be. But the issues around the question of the Victorian Auditor-General were certainly something that many members of the committee had serious concerns about, although they recognised in the circumstances that we could not, in fact, deal with the issues at hand.

I seek leave to continue my remarks when the debate is resumed.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That:
(1) Standing order 193 (When division may be taken) be amended by omitting the second paragraph and substituting:

Provided that, on sitting Mondays, any division called for in the House on a question, other than a motion moved by a Minister, prior to questions without notice being called on or during presentation of petitions or private Members' business, shall stand deferred until the grievance debate has concluded or been postponed.
(2) Standing order 248 be amended to read:

248 When the House disagrees to any amendments of the Senate to a bill, the Member who moved the motion—That the amendment(s) be disagreed to—shall present to the House written reasons for the House not agreeing to the amendments proposed by the Senate. A message returning the bill to the Senate shall contain any such reasons.
(3) Standing order 258 be amended to read:

para.inline: Reasons for disagreeing to further Senate amendments

speech.para: 258 When the House disagrees to any amendments made by the Senate to the amendments of the House, the Member who moved the motion—That the amendment(s) be disagreed to—shall present to the House written reasons for the House not agreeing to the amendments made by the Senate. A message returning the bill to the Senate shall contain any such reasons.
(4) The following sessional orders concerning the operation of the Main Committee be adopted as standing orders:
(a) 81 (Debate confined to present question—Exceptions);
(b) 91 (Time limits);
(c) 274 (Sittings and adjournment);
(d) 274A (Adjournment debates);
(e) 275A (Statements by Members); and
(f) 276 (How questions decided—Division not possible).

This motion before the House addresses four matters. The fourth matter simply relates to the sessional orders being adopted as standing orders in respect of the Main Committee, and I do not need, therefore, to say any more about that. The three other substantive issues relate to standing order 193, standing order 248, and the reasons for disagreeing to further Senate amendments.

The amendment to standing order 193 provides that on sitting Mondays any divisions on motions moved by a private member prior to question time or during petitions in the second period of private members' busi ness shall be deferred until after the grievance debate has been concluded or postponed. Under this proposal, divisions arising during petitions and committee and delegation reports would be treated similarly to divisions during private members business under standing order 193 as it currently stands, except that, under the standing order as amended, divisions will also be called on if the grievance debate is postponed.

This issue was originally raised by the Clerk of the House and was subsequently referred to the Standing Committee on Procedure, which I am pleased to say supports the amendment. I thank the chair of the committee, the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) for his advice that the proposed change is, in fact, consistent with the intention of the original 1988 amendment of the standing orders in relation to the deferral of divisions.

Standing order 193 was amended in 1998 to provide that any divisions called for on sitting Thursdays before 12.30 be deferred. Under the then routine of business, this period covered private members business, committee and delegation reports and presentations of petitions. The proposed amendment is a sensible proposal that I commend to the House.

In respect of standing orders 248 and 258, members will be aware that, where the Senate makes amendments to bills passed by the House, the standing orders require an unnecessarily formalistic and cumbersome process if the House disagrees with the Senate amendments. Standing orders 248 and 258 require that, where any Senate amendments are disagreed to by the House, the House must appoint a committee of three members to draw up reasons for the disagreement. The reasons must then be reported to the House. The committee's reasons, when agreed to by the House, must then be transmitted to the Senate by the message returning the bill.

As all members know, this process is purely procedural and adds nothing to the consideration of particular amendments. In fact, the House of Representatives Practice notes, not only in the current third edition but also in the second edition published in 1989, that the process can be somewhat cumbersome and has been subject to some derision. New members have been bemused by this process whereby the House decides to appoint a committee and voila!—the committee meets and immediately produces a very carefully worded statement to represent their views.

talk.start.para: —It is detailed and comprehensive; that's why we disagree.

—Exactly. Removing the obsolete requirement for a committee of reasons will not reduce the scope for debate of amendments or the possibility of a compromise between the House and Senate in respect of disputed amendments. The arguments for rejecting particular amendments will still be explained, debated and voted on when the minister moves that the amendments be disagreed to. Ministers will be required to present reasons to the House for disagreeing with amendments. These written reasons will be incorporated into the message to the Senate without time being wasted on procedures which do not add anything to the functioning of parliament. Consistent with the government's practice of reviewing sensible proposals for reforming the standing orders, this issue has been referred to the Procedure Committee for advice. I am pleased to say that the committee supports this proposed amendment.

speech.para: In respect of the other matters I first mentioned, the government proposes that the sessional orders relating to the provision of members' three-minute statements in adjournment debates when the Main Committee meets on Thursdays be adopted as standing orders. They were introduced in December 1997. These orders were seen as an important measure to increase the time and opportunities for members to speak on issues in the parliament. They arose from the report of the Procedure Committee of September 1997 entitled Provision for members to make short speeches in the Main Committee.

While the Procedure Committee proposed 90-second member statements in the Main Committee on Thursday mornings, the government considered that three minutes was a more appropriate time limit. I note that the government acted on representations from both government and opposition members in this regard. The sessional orders were proposed to apply for the autumn and winter sittings this year on a trial basis. It seems that the trial has worked pretty well, allowing an additional 40 members to speak during the adjournment debates and 43 members to make three-minute statements so far this year, thereby adding over five hours of debating time to members for these purposes—three hours for adjournment and two hours and 10 minutes for three-minute statements. Given the success of these orders and the general support for these procedures on both sides of the House, the sessional orders should be adopted as standing orders of the House rather than lapse whenever the House is dissolved. I understand, and hope, that the opposition also supports this proposal, as they did the introduction of the measures on a trial basis.

That reasonably canvasses the matters currently before the chair in these proposed amendments to standing orders. I commend them all to the House. I conclude my remarks by thanking those who have been associated with making these sensible reforms.

talk.start.para: —Name them.

—The member for Aston for one; the people in my office. I will not give you credit because you are known for taking it without invitation, and will probably do so now. The member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) has been a strong supporter for changes to procedures. This government has taken the attitude—
—I got you a lift up.
—Thanks very much.
—He would not have done it otherwise.
—He did.
—I did actually mention the member for Aston earlier. The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) did not listen, which is what the people in Queensland were telling us 10 days ago.
—Thank you.
—Why do you have to thank him?

—Because you interjected, as usual. We do work to lift the standards of the parliament and the constant interjections of the member for Hotham are evidence again why there is a continuing need to try to improve standards. One way to improve standards is to enhance the opportunities for people to speak. These sessional orders have done that. The other changes streamline processes, thereby making more time for members to address the House on issues which they consider important.

speech.para: This government has given a high priority to improving standards in the House. That is evident from some of the statistics, which demonstrate the extent to which we have changed processes and procedures. For example, during question time we now have many more questions than were ever allowed when Labor was in office. The average length of time for question time in 1996 was 74 minutes; in 1997 it was 74.8 minutes. The average number of questions asked during question time in 1996 was 19.5; in 1997 it was 19.6. This is almost double the number of questions which were allowed when Labor was in office. They are the best numbers since 1976.

When Mr Keating was in, he treated the parliament with absolute contempt. In fact, he said that question time was a courtesy extended by the executive to the parliament. The number of questions asked during 1996 was 1,192; in 1997 it was 1,519. This is almost double the number of questions allowed to be asked when Labor was in. In fact, these numbers are the best numbers in over 20 years—the best numbers since 1976.

The most number of bills declared urgent was 12 bills in 1997, which is down from the number when Labor was in office—in 1992 they had 132 whipped through the parliament under a declaration of urgency. By any statistic this government has provided opportunities for members to speak and for parliamentary standards to be raised, and the statistics demonstrate it very clearly. Even the fact that we now have question time at 2 o'clock was a change introduced by this government. When Labor was in office, Mr Keating did not like question time being televised, so he arranged for question time to be held at 3 o'clock because he knew the ABC preferred to run Sesame Street instead of the national parliament!

talk.start.para: —That's right.

—`That's right,' says the member for Cunningham. Then the Speaker of the House, known for coming into this parliament metaphorically with a bruised eye, having done a couple of rounds with Mr Keating—
—Never.
—Metaphorically.
—Not even that.
—Mr Keating was the one who said that we had not had a decent Speaker since Billy Snedden. That was when you were the Speaker—and you remember that, don't you?
—I don't remember it.

—Exactly. We have transformed the arrangements for question time. But for the interjections and irrelevant points of order we constantly have from the Labor Party, we would be doing even better with more precise and succinct question times than we have.
—And what about the RDOs?

—The member for Aston reminds me of the incredible, if not bizarre, practice when Labor was in office that the ministers only had to turn up every second day. They had a rostered day off, so a minister who was under pressure one day did not have to turn up the next. When the idea was introduced, it was on the basis that they would be out talking to the people. But we used to find that on their RDOs, were they out talking with people in the supermarkets and in the highways and byways? No, they would be sitting back in their office watching question time on the monitor, having afternoon tea! We know that because the statistics show that on the days when those ministers were rostered off, when we had a division in the afternoon all of a sudden they would turn up.

speech.para: It is timely to note that the changes that we have made have been to improve parliamentary standards. By looking at the statistics, you can see what a very significant change has been introduced. The fact of the matter is that when Labor were in they treated the parliament with absolute contempt. We intend to go on reminding people that the attitude of the previous Labor government was such that on many occasions people failed to have the opportunity to raise issues that should have been raised.

One of the reasons that people have been turning away from the major political parties is that for 13 years, if you had a different point of view from the Labor government's, you were just wiped. The rise of Pauline Hanson's party or David Oldfield's party or David Ettridge's party—

talk.start.para: —The three owners.

—The three owners. One of them is on a 12 per cent take; whichever one is running it. The rise of that party is a reflection that a lot of people felt disenfranchised by the political process. The reason for that was that the previous Labor government dismissed the genuine concerns of many Australians. Even today, as question time got under way, was the Labor Party asking questions about unemployment and the things that really concern people? No, they were not, because they still fail to focus on the genuinely significant issues for the vast bulk of the Australian population.

speech.para: I will cut short my time as I have had the opportunity to put what needs to be put on the public record. I dare say we will get the usual diatribe from the member for Hotham, who will be unable and incapable of addressing himself to the motion before the chair. I will wait five minutes to see if he says anything of substance. If he does not, I will get back to the office for afternoon tea.

I know that he will support these amendments. When we came into office, we took all the Procedure Committee reports that had been shelved and were sitting, collecting dust, and we said to the committee, `Go back over every report which was shelved by the Labor Party, update them all, bring us back a set of recommendations and we will actually respond to the recommendations.' We did that, we brought in a swathe of new reforms as soon as we were elected and today's matters, whilst not as bold as some of the other parlia mentary reforms that we have introduced, are still important in themselves. They reflect the fact that, as a government, where there are good ideas to improve the procedures in the House we willingly accept them. Unlike under Labor, they do not gather dust; we get on and make things happen. I commend this motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —We do support the standing and sessional orders proposals that have come forward. The Leader of the House (Mr Reith) could not help himself and did divert and became so patronising, as usual. Understand that this is the guy who is saying he is lifting standards but, instead of staying in here to listen to the response, he has got better things to do: go and have a cup of tea. He is still chasing the votes. He has lost so heavily in the waterfront dispute—P1 has caught so far up; the old P2 is miles behind—so he is back to afternoon teas and counting the votes—
—With the backbenchers.
—With the backbenchers. He has two of them in here today: one of them will not be back, the other may not be. This is the Leader of the House; how patronising!

speech.para: Not only do we have the patronising image in this place, we have the public persona of a minister who just cannot be believed. When he was talking during the waterfront dispute about how he knew nothing about the decision by Patrick's to sack its work force and replace it with another—and this was back in April—only 10 per cent of the Australian public believed him. I think that has plummeted to probably 0.01 per cent after his performance in the last couple of days. He is a minister who cannot be believed, a person who just patronises and knows no other way. The propositions that are before us do make sense, and we support them.

talk.start.para: —Will you congratulate the government for introducing them?

—I do indicate that in relation to one of them, the statement of reasons, the government had to be goaded into supporting the position that they now adopt because of pressure from the opposition. We heard the Leader of the House talk about standing orders 248 and 258, which remove the fiction of the appointment of a committee of reasons to provide reasons for the House disagreeing with Senate amendments. We think it is a fiction that the resolution is that the committee be appointed and, within seconds, the committee is reporting. So we do not have a problem with getting rid of the fiction. Our complaint was that we never got any reasons. It was not the fiction of the committee, it was the fact that the Leader of the House, who is at the table, could not be bothered giving reasons as to why the government was prepared to disagree with the motions that came back from the Senate.

speech.para: Do you know what this government wanted to do? Not only did it want to knock off the fiction, but it also wanted to knock off the requirement to give reasons. And here he is preaching accountability. Here are motions coming back from the Senate that require earnest attention by a government claiming to be accountable and claiming to be representative of the people who elected it, but it does not want to be put in a position where it has to give reasons. This is not purely procedural; this comes back to the requirement for the government to give reasons. It wanted to avoid doing that and it was only under pressure from the Labor Party that we now have that position.

As for the sessional orders becoming standing orders, we agree with that. The proposals that were put in as sessional orders and trialled were effectively implemented in the Main Committee. Most of these deal with the Main Committee so we do not have a problem, following that, in having them become standing orders. The decision in relation to standing order 193 makes sense in terms of deferral of divisions to make sure that it is not only private members business to which the deferral applies but also committee and government reports, the presentation of petitions and members' 90-second statements.

These things will streamline the activities of the parliament, but we have to say that it is wasted on this government. It is a government that wants to streamline procedures but cannot actually get any business of substance into this House in the last sitting fortnight. Here we are languishing around because this government cannot organise any legislation of note to bring forward. Here we are noting papers, debating on sessional orders and all of those sorts of things—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. These comments are irrelevant to the matter before the House and, furthermore, they misrepresent the position on the programming. The reason that people have an opportunity to speak on these matters is because private members have asked to be able to speak on them.
—The honourable member for Hotham will remain relevant to the motion before the House.

—On that point of order, I would just draw your attention to what the Leader of the House was departing from the motion before the House on. He was talking about how they had increased the number of questions in the parliament, how they had raised parliamentary standards, how they got rid of the RDOs—and he wants to take me on a point of order? You have got to be joking. What hypocrisy!

speech.para: Here we have a government, this week and last week, struggling to get business before the parliament. Contrast that with the previous fortnight, where everything was urgent. It had something like 31 bills it had to get through, and it put a requirement on us that we had to get through 21 of those bills in 27 hours of debate. Just imagine that. This is a government that says, `This is the people's House. We want more debate. We want greater accountability'—but it wants to ram these pieces of legislation through, and now it has not got enough business to keep itself going. My point is that there are important pieces of legislation that this government promised to bring forward but has not, and why aren't they before the House this week? Take, for example, the legislation freezing the car tariffs and the legislation that replaces the export scheme for the car industry. Both of those were agreements that this government entered into more than 12 months ago. It promised to introduce legislation before this parliament rose, and it has not done it. And this could well be the last week that the parliament sits. The case with textiles is similar.

He has to go for his cup of tea now. Let everyone note that the minister has more important things to do—like having a cup of tea—than hearing about his hopeless mismanagement of this parliament and the fact that they are not prepared to honour promises they made to the Australian public and to industry.

talk.start.para: —What?

—You said that you would have legislation before this parliament on the car tariff freeze. It is not here. You said that you would have legislation before this parliament on the textile, clothing and footwear tariff freeze. You have not done it. The minister said that they would soon have legislation to address the negative assistance for the book publishing industry. It is not here. We had a government saying that it was prepared, if it had time, to introduce—in relation to the anti-dumping legislation—the correction of China being treated as a market economy. There is no legislation. Why can't it have that legislation before the parliament? It cannot be a lack of drafting capacity. It cannot be that there is no time. These things have been on the record for ages.

speech.para: On the question of time, do we remember how much time it took them to get the stevedoring levy bill before the House? Patrick's, backed by this government, sacked its whole work force at 11 o'clock on Tuesday night and, on Wednesday morning at 10 o'clock, this government had special legislation in the parliament, backing the sackings. Some coincidence! This was complicated legislation. This is a government that gave priority to sacking workers, not protecting workers' jobs in the car and textile industries. This is a government that was prepared to draft legislation overnight to sack workers. We saw images of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business slapping each other on the back, congratulating each other for this great piece of legislation that backs the sacking of workers and backs arrangements whereby Patrick's can strip the assets of its company and put the employment contracts in the hands of shell companies—a $300 million asset company which left $52,000 in the labour hire accounts to pay 2,000 workers. And this government backed them. This government allowed that legislation through.

Worse, when they had the Corporations Law before the House, which we amended, and which the Senate agreed with us on, to ensure that that Patrick's scam, the Corrigan scam, could not happen again, who stuck their hands up in support of protecting workers' security? Labor did. Who opposed it? The coalition did. The coalition are prepared to have lie on the statute books legislation that will enable what was done with Patrick's to be done again. Yet they go around the country talking about the need for security of the work force. What a sham. What hypocrisy. What cant. Why haven't we got the legislation before this parliament that would actually put some protective support under thousands of workers in this country, under those employed in the automotive industry, those employed in the textile, clothing and footwear industry and those employed in the book publishing industry? There are people whose jobs are threatened by dumped product coming in from countries which are now even more inclined to dump because of the Asian economic crisis. For example, there are the people in the paper making industry. People are threatened by cheap products being dumped here, putting our workers at risk. We have already seen the first instalment of that, quite frankly, with Burnie closing its pulp mill because this government failed to lift its hand.

What we see here, therefore, is a government that waxes lyrical about streamlining the parliament, making it more accountable, but whose actions say, `Don't talk to us about bringing legislation into the place. Don't get us on any serious business. We will streamline it so much that we don't have to do anything.' On this issue of the government now handling more questions than we did, they might get more questions but the trouble is that we do not get any answers. Who has been the greatest obfuscator of the lot: the minister for industrial relations, who has just left to have his cup of tea. Did you ever hear him answer a straight question on his involvement in the Dubai affair; on his state of knowledge of Patrick's decision to sack its entire work force and replace it with another; or on his involvement with the Prime Minister, backed by a departmental minute that recommended, step by step, the very consequences of what took place on the Melbourne wharf and led to the wholesale sacking of the totality of the Patrick's work force? Here we had the shifty minister saying he knew nothing about the Dubai incident but refusing to answer about his state of knowledge of other plans.

On 8 May this year he went public and said he had no knowledge about any plans by Patrick's, and neither did anyone in the government. The trouble is that we caught him out. We caught him out with a document that was presented in this parliament, which the government refused to accept being tabled. So much, again, for accountability. The document demonstrated that, as far back as 14 April last year, this government—including the Prime Minister, including the minister for workplace relations, including the former minister for transport, John Sharp—were up to their necks not just in backing the Patrick strategy but in being asked to be involved as participants in engineering a wholesale dispute on the waterfront. There was external activity to ensure we got a close-down of the waterfront. Of course, the minister tries to put out that when we were in government we looked at such things as deregistration and the like. The fact of the matter is that we did not seriously consider those things. They might have come by way of recommendations but they were dismissed by us, and the recommendations came only after a dispute had occurred. On the other hand, this is a government that has been complicit in engineering the very activities that led to the dispute and that has been prepared to back illegal actions involving itself in a conspiracy.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member for Hotham will get back directly to the motion.
