subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 29 June, on motion by Mr Hawker:
That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —In concluding my remarks of yesterday, I would like to reiterate the importance of the competition policy and the work that the National Competition Council is doing. I would also like to remind honourable members that the work of this council came from the COAG meeting in 1995 when the Commonwealth, state and territory governments all agreed to the introduction of competition policy and its implementation. The current report builds on some of the work that the committee has already done, both with the major report, Cultivating competition , which was tabled last year, and the work it does with the ACCC.

speech.para: We have made a number of recommendations to the government, most of which have been taken up. The one we made in this current report, Review of the National Competition Council annual report 1996-97, was the importance of ensuring that the public is properly educated on the value of competition, how it is being implemented, where it is not being implemented and why it is not being implemented.

I again thank all members of the committee for their support. It was a unanimous report and I think that the committee does work very well in a bipartisan way, and it does demonstrate how a standing committee of the parliament can achieve a lot of very good work which I believe does enhance the reputation of the parliament. I also thank the secretariat for their support, particularly Bev Forbes, Chris Paterson and all the others who support the Financial Institutions and Public Administration Committee. They certainly do put in a lot of hard work and, with their support, we are able to produce some excellent reports.

This is my third time I have spoken on this report. I conclude with those few remarks and emphasise that the committee has made a recommendation and that we look forward to a positive response from the government.

talk.start.para: —I certainly welcome this report, Review of the National Competition Council annual report 1996-97 , and the work of the Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration in reviewing the process of national competition policy in Australia. I should start by outlining my surprise that we have not got a conga line of National Party members lining up, based on their recent rhetoric, to outline the so-called evils of competition policy. Perhaps those National Party members are out making their latest name change. There is a nice sequence in this: Country Party, National Country Party, National Party, and now the simple name change to One Nation—if not by their choice, then perhaps by the people.

speech.para: They have been part of a process—somewhat common in the populism and demonisation now sweeping across Australian politics—to try to make competition a dirty word. I would pose the question: how else do you run a market based economy other than with competition? How do you make markets work without the discipline and the upgrading capacity of simple competition between corporations and, if need be, between government entities? This is a simple proposition: dogs bark, markets compete. There is no way of running a market based economy without the disciplines of competition.

If that is not evident enough to those in this parliament, they should simply look elsewhere. Would anyone go to North Korea, with its policy of isolationism, and pretend that that is better for economic growth and potential than market based competition? The Hanson approach, of course, is a mirror reflection of North Korea, where there are people starving in the streets because they cannot generate the economic growth to feed their people. Would one go to Eastern Europe and ask any economist or public policy official, or indeed any citizen, whether central planning was a better way of running an economy than market based competition? All of these things have been tried and they have failed.

One of the emerging truths for people on the social democratic side of politics is to give up on trying to replace market based competition with some other form of production, distribution and exchange. The social democratic task now is to civilise global capital to ameliorate the impact of globalisation on society, its cohesiveness and its basic community values. This is a project that social democrats can embrace. But to try to replace market based systems with some other form of production is effectively a distraction from the central goal of social democrats in a globalised economy.

Markets have proven themselves to be an effective engine of growth, but we cannot pretend, of course, that markets always get it right. As a rule of thumb, I work on the assumption that markets get it right in the allocation of economic resources 60 to 70 per cent of the time. In some of the fundamentals of life in Australia, market based competition is the clearing house for consumer choice and lifestyle. We do not try to centrally plan supermarkets or food distribution in Australia, or the distribution of clothing. No-one would ever pretend that you need to replace market based competition on those fundamentals of life with some other form of production or distribution. But in those cases where markets get it wrong, where there are externalities, environmental and social, where markets have an undesirable impact on society and income distribution, an undesirable impact on culture and community, there is an active role for government to play. So on 30 to 40 per cent of occasions markets may fail and may require active government intervention to make corrections, to give society cohesiveness, to give strength to community values and to achieve a fairer distribution of income and social capacity.

What should governments do in those interventions? The worst thing a government can do is to smother competition and create a dependency relationship with the private sector. In framing interventions, especially in a globalised economy, the worst thing government can do is to try and smother competition and create some form of dependency relationship with the corporate sector. We hear the other side of politics talking about these things with regard to social welfare. It is true that in a post-industrial society transfer payments without new skills and responsibilities ultimately hurt the recipients of social welfare. That is a truth that I think all sides of politics are now facing up to. Transfer payments without new skills and responsibilities ultimately create long-term welfare dependency, and that is undesirable.

So, too, that principle applies when it comes to the corporate sector. Handouts to the corporate sector without the disciplines of market competition also ultimately hurt the recipients. I had a reminder of this when I was on a study tour in New Zealand, where a New Zealand metal manufacturer in Christchurch said to me, `Look, under the old regime, the policies of Muldoon and the like in New Zealand, there were protection, subsidies and regulation, and it was a licence to print money. Every time my company got into trouble, the government would bail me out. So I just relied on the government handouts, the government protection and the government subsidies to underscore my profit line and I did no innovation and no upgrading. I did not try to change my work practices and did not try to engage in outward strategies to expand my markets. I had a licence to print money from government.' That is a telltale sign of how you can smother the market mechanism with too much government intervention and protection. You do need certain disciplines in competition policy to make markets work.

This manufacturer expressed to me his initial opposition to the changes in New Zealand policy in the 1980s, but they forced upon him and his business innovation, upgrading and change in work practices—all the things that make markets work. When I visited in 1995, that business was engaging in innovation, R&D on the factory floor, to produce a plastic engine for motorbikes. This is a long way from guaranteed government income and profit support: ambitious plans to try and build an innovative base for exports and manufacturing potential. Just as it can be argued that social welfare recipients propped up by long-term welfare dependency are suffering for that government policy, so too it can be argued that that applies just as much to the relationship between the public sector and the corporate sector.

I would argue that, when it comes to social and business wellbeing, you need a soft heart but also a hard head. The hard head says that competition policy is a useful discipline in a market based economy. For the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and his fellow travellers around the backblocks of Queensland who say that is not the case, let them point to a place where some other system has worked better. They can never do it. Schumpeter, the economist, 100 years ago described this as creative destruction, and that is true.

talk.start.para: —A hundred years ago?
—Well, he was born a hundred years ago.
—He wrote in the forties.

—He might have been writing in the 1940s, but he was born a hundred years ago. He was an Austrian from that era. I think he was born around the same year that Marx died, in 1883. He was at school, hopefully prospering from better school policies in Austria in the 1880s than you are giving to Australia in the 1990s.

speech.para: Schumpeter described this process as creative destruction—markets can create a lot of wealth and economic opportunity but so too they can be disruptive of some of the fundamentals of a cohesive society. They can destroy some businesses and destroy some of the opportunities for a fairer distribution of income and social opportunity. This is where the active role for government comes into play. Earlier tonight I was at the Canberra branch of the Economics Society listening to Fred Argy give a precis of his new book. He provided what I thought was an outstanding way to consider the economic debate and the way this parliament should look at it now. That is basically to say that we are all economic liberals now. That was the message: we are all economic liberals now; it is just a matter of what sort of economic liberalism and market freedom we bring to bear.

What Fred Argy said, I think quite perceptively, was that progressive economic liberals would believe in four things. The first was that markets, all other things being equal, are an effective way of allocating economic resources. Second, all other things being equal, competition policy is good. Third, markets fail and governments need to intervene in those circumstances. The fourth proposition is that markets produce poor distributional outcomes in society, again justifying government interventions.

On the third and fourth points, with regard to market failure and distributional questions, the big challenge for social democrats is to work out what sort of interventions and distributional strategies are needed, as the movement of capital has gone from the national sphere to global arenas. There are new market circumstances and new policy requirements for social democrats wanting to do the government intervention well and wanting to bring fairer distributional outcomes to society.

I sign up as a progressive economic liberal and I cannot see how anyone would believe in any other approach to economic matters or a report like this. Of course, there are some, led by the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) over here, who would be described within the Argy schema as a hard economic liberal. They do not believe that markets fail all that much and, even if they do, governments will not do much about it. Their final proposition is that the less government does the better off we will be.

That approach, I believe, is ultimately destructive to our social fabric, ultimately unfair on the distribution of income and opportunity, and a recipe for individualism and social fragmentation. In any case, it is not proven that any of that hard economic liberalism that we might find from Dr Kemp is going to produce any better economic outcome than the more progressive approach. I think it is very important to understand these things. For those who use competition policy as some form of demon, some form of populist rhetoric—talking about the money power and the Depression in the 1930s—it is incumbent upon them to explain how, without the disciplines of competition in a market based economy, we can get any better result for this country.

I have not heard any explanation among the utterings and murmurs of Bob Katter—I think he speaks on these things only if a television camera is in front of him—on the far right or the rantings of someone like Phil Cleary on the far left, or from the Hansonites or the Democrats, who have a unity ticket on economic policy, of what they would replace the current system with. They have no explanation because history and logic tell them that there is no superior system to the competition disciplines of the market based economy providing also for an active role for government.

The active role for government is important, and I think it is changing. I have argued that in a dynamic, globally focused economy there can be consistency with a fair society. Important things need to be done on the distributional front, such as having a decent and indexed minimum wage, particularly in industries where there is very little opportunity for substitution between labour and capital. I have argued the importance of civil sector employment as a way of filling the gaps left on a spatial or a regional scale by the failings of the profit system. I have argued the importance of regional infrastructure and services.

And the most important point in this debate—and why I think Australia has gone backwards—is that we can prepare people for change only by giving them new skills and new ways of acting and responding to the change process. This is the problem with the debate. I was listening to Bill Clinton on CNN, talking at the Beijing University. To think that you could describe him as a politician on the one hand and our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) as a politician is absolutely ridiculous—they are as different as chalk and cheese. The Prime Minister has driven Australia into a state of funk; no talk and no leadership about how people can prepare for change, just always the constant attempt to patch things up and try to hold over the political agenda until the next poll comes in and gives him a bit of respite. It is the work of a small person locked in the past.

Clinton is always talking about preparing people for change, skilling them, giving them new opportunities and education, and making them understand that the only way we can respond in an era of uncertainty is to prepare people for change. In an era of permanent change, prepare for it, is the message that this government needs to give to the people of Australia. If it does not give that sort of message, we will stay in this state of funk, pessimism and depression; and every two-bit populist in town who wants to raise an issue and try to scare people will get a platform to do it because there is no leadership explaining the alternative. That is what has changed in Australia over the last two years. That is the thing that has fundamentally changed on the Australian political agenda. As reflected in government policy, this is not an administration that is prepared to invest in Australia's future by growing the national commitment to education, research and training.

I want to conclude with a final point about political communication. I do not endorse what Bob Hogg is doing with that ridiculous campaign supporting the GST. He was talking about communication. There are some fools in the press gallery who get onto these things. Tim Colebatch in the Age today described the GST as the best option in tax reform. He was having a go at me not so long ago, saying that a progressive expenditure tax would fold because it could not be made progressive. His answer on progressive tax was a GST so I do not endorse Colebatch, who is an imbecile, and I certainly do not endorse what Bob Hogg is doing with his strategy in tandem with Singleton. But I think Bob Hogg is right in terms of the political debate and the national understanding of issues like competition policy. He said:

I am sick of the fact that you can't have a dialogue in this country. Part of the reason for what is happening at the moment with the 20-odd per cent of dissent for One Nation showing up is that nobody's explaining. Forget this business of not talking and listening; that is just so much nonsense. People expect government to do things but they like to know why, what is the purpose and what is the long and short-term benefit of what they are doing. When you have a vacuum every bit of discontent, evil or otherwise, will congeal. It is the lack of debate on the public policy that is the real problem. I mean, if we can't have a debate about reforms, in the end when it's all over people can say, yes I can support that or no I can't. It's how democracy works. We've been denying it for a while. Part of democracy is about educating by debate and explaining. What's wrong with them, it's not guns we're talking about, it's ideas, for God's sake.

If this government had any courage and any leadership, and propagated the right ideas and explanation to the Australian people about issues like competition policy, we would have the potential for strong, long-term economic growth, a dynamic market based economy with sufficient government interventions to do the things that also make our society fair. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Taylor) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by Mr Taylor:
That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —I want to make a few brief comments in the time available to me this evening in continuation of debate on the tabling of what is a very major report—the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade into the level of funding required for the defence of Australia. I am pleased that the opposition's defence spokesman, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), is in the House because I want to take the opportunity to say to him and to others in this place and beyond that this is a major report, which would not have been possible without a very strong dose of bipartisanship, with the exception of the predictable dissenting report by Senator Margetts. Senator Margetts very rarely says things that are pertinent to the Defence debate—other than rather ideologically driven issues—nevertheless, at the end of my contribution I want to come back to what she had to say because there is a modicum of truth in one or two things she has said in this report.

speech.para: There are only seven recommendations in this report. They are very important recom mendations. I would like to highlight two of them this evening. One is recommendation 4, which says:
The Committee recommends that the mechanism of fixing a rate of real growth be adopted as a means of defining the increase in Defence spending.
The second is recommendation No. 7, which says:
The Committee is concerned about the substantial additional expenditure required to overcome block obsolescence in the 2010-2015 period.

I hope the opposition spokesman on defence will lend his support to the reaction, albeit the interim reaction, from the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) in which he said that this report is a very useful input into the government's considerations. In particular he highlighted the substantial additional expenditure to overcome the block obsolescence of that major equipment. He went on to say that the government is very conscious of these pressures and, although Defence outlays as a percentage of GDP had fallen by 0.8 per cent—from 2.6 per cent to 1.8 per cent—under the previous government, the Howard government had committed itself to halt the decline and to hold Defence outlays at the levels set out in the 1995-96 budget. I feel sure that the opposition spokesman on defence will have something to say about that.

On the issue of scrutiny: as somebody who has been involved in Defence matters for over three decades and in this parliament for another decade, I do not think there has been one department that has been more scrutinised inside and out than the Department of Defence. It often cops it with both barrels—to put it in military parlance—which at times I think is somewhat unjustified. However, I think over the last four or five years there have been a number of programs that have fallen well short of accountability and real accountability in public outlay terms. I will make mention of that when I come back to Senator Margetts's dissenting report.

It is true that a lot of the scrutiny outside the Department of Defence continues, whether it is from the Department of Finance and Administration, from the National Audit Office or from this parliament. That is where this report I think serves a very functional purpose in the accountability chain. I am sure that the opposition spokesman on defence will have some comments to make on this as well.
In terms of the block obsolescence and in relation to the fixing of a rate of around two per cent real growth in Defence funding, the report says in part:
a significant number of things we would like to be able to do start to become possible under a line at about two per cent real growth in the Defence budget.
That is what the Department of Defence said in their evidence. The report went on to say:

12.17 From Defence's explanations of the difficulties it would face, even given two per cent real growth, the Committee was surprised at Defence claims that this level of increase would enable capabilities to be developed. A real growth of two per cent falls below the levels of funding claimed as necessary minimums in the 1987 and 1994 Defence White Paper's . . .
It went on:

12.18 The Department provided no objective evidence specifically supporting its calculation of the need for two per cent real growth, and was generally unforthcoming on such detail throughout the inquiry.
It finished by saying:

12.19 The Committee was left with the task of validating the increase required through use of other evidence. The need for planning to address the block obsolescence problem was accepted as the most compelling long-term factor. The F/A-18 replacement alone will require additional funding in the order of $5 to $12 billion, which Defence claims cannot be accommodated within long-term major capital investment planning. Allowance to make this sum available would require a real growth rate averaging between one and 2.5 per cent to the current Defence funding level, sustained over a decade. By including the requirement to replace the Adelaide class frigates, and to replace the F-111 in the longer term, a real growth rate significantly above 2.5 per cent would be required, and would need to be sustained across the longer term, to inject these estimated funding requirements into the Defence budget.

I think that is a very salient section from the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee's report. Also in terms of the measure of Defence expenditure, the report says—and I think this is very pertinent to the argument:

2.41 The weight of arguments against defining Defence funding as a proportion of GDP or of Commonwealth Budget Outlays dictate that neither method should be used. Definition in terms of GDP or Commonwealth Budget Outlays produces a variable outcome subject to the external influences on those measures. Defence believes that:
The most useful measure for quantifying the level of Defence funding is the real change to the [funding] base over time.

That is what the committee has concluded. We put that forward to the minister for the cabinet consideration in due course. I think it will always be the case that a percentage of GDP and a percentage of Commonwealth outlays are measures of expenditure within the Defence portfolio. But what the committee recommended, in line with the views of the Department of Defence, is that we move to a more finite measure of Defence expenditure to reflect this real increase over a period of time.

I want to come back to Senator Margetts's dissenting report. A lot of what Senator Margetts says in the defence arena is, in my view, very irrelevant. It is ideologically driven in the main. This particular dissenting report is, in many ways, no exception. However, I think both sides in this place should be concerned about the track record of some of the major projects in the defence arena. In her dissenting report, Senator Margetts highlights—and I have some sympathy with what she says—the Collins class submarine program and the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar network program. I noticed in the newspapers this morning that there is now a report of major problems with the gas turbine main propulsion in the Anzac class frigates.

There is something wrong in the acquisition process. I would suggest that the solution lies with the Defence Acquisition Review Board. I think it was during the last sitting week that the shadow minister for defence and I had some briefings on the function of that review board. It may in many ways ameliorate some of the criticism of the Department of Defence, which is spending big bucks. There is no way around it—Defence has to be more accountable for these large amounts of money.

There is no doubt that the Collins class submarines will be a major acquisition of and a major asset to the Australian Defence Force once some of the software problems and quality control aspects of that program are sorted out. The same goes for Jindalee. But I think that, until such time as the Department of Defence is able to put its hand on its heart and say, `We are totally accountable; we have this acquisition review process in place,' the department is reasonably open to some objective criticism.

I am one of those who would objectively criticise some of these programs. I do not think it helps to unnecessarily attribute party political blame in relation to some of these projects. Yes, of course both sides from time to time bear the weight of the decisions that they take. The Collins decision was a good decision, in my view. Whilst we could criticise the opposition's decision on that program now, in the short term I do not think it helps the overall defence debate if we have a preoccupation with criticising things that happened in the past. I think we have to look forward and be positive in terms of some of these programs.

I make the point once again that this is a major report, although it is a relatively small report. I congratulate Senator David MacGibbon and the whole committee for bringing it together in a relatively short period of time. It is appropriate that the government be given the points that are made in this report in a timely fashion, and I think that has been done. The arguments that are mounted in it are objective. We should congratulate both sides of the House on the strong, bipartisan nature of the recommendations. I hope that what it says will not fall on deaf ears. This government has done a lot on defence in a short time. The opposition spokesman may have a contrary view when he gets on his feet. Nevertheless, we have had the defence efficiency review. We have now got the ongoing defence reform program. We have had a strategic review. All that cannot be bad. Nevertheless, the proof of the defence pudding will be in the eating thereof. I hope that the government will take this report very seriously and agree in general terms with the thrust of the recommendations.

talk.start.para: —I join with the member for Groom (Mr Taylor) and others in this debate in encouraging both the House and the public to take up this report and have a close look at it. It is a welcome and valuable contribution to an important debate: the national security of Australia, its people and its primary interests.

speech.para: It is, I suspect, the first occasion—it is certainly a rare occasion—on which a bipartisan committee of the parliament has sat down to look at the level of resources required by the Australian Defence Force in order to defend our nation properly. It is a pity, in many ways, that the focus on this parliament is usually a 90-second or 60-second grab out of question time. The work of committees like this one and reports like this are earnest and genuine efforts on a bipartisan basis to look at most serious questions. It is a pity that these things attract the attention of few, if any, in the press gallery and probably only a few in the defence community itself. Parliamentary committees are where so much of the important work of members of parliament is undertaken.

The report makes a series of recommendations about the way in which we should gauge the levels of funding required. The member for Groom has referred to that, so I will not go over that ground, other than to say that I think the report's recommendations are very sound in that respect. The report has the limitation that the committee took evidence and worked assiduously with the support of one specialist person, one support staff member, from Defence. The committee looked in some detail at what funding was required for the Australian Defence Force for the next four to five years, and then it looked at projected funding for a decade beyond that period. We did that with one specialist support person. The Department of Defence has about 120 people trying to do the same task.

Obviously, with those limitations it is not possible to come up with a definitive answer. I do not think the committee purports to have produced a definitive answer to what is required for Australia's defence, but it has made a damn good effort at it. The report identifies a number of important areas that require further attention, and it has given its best effort in saying, `This is the sort of money the country needs to look at if it is to maintain the necessary defence capability that is important for our nation as we move into the 21st century.'

I want to address a couple of concerns that I as shadow minister for defence have and I want to take the opportunity to set a few of the historical facts straight. In the 1996 election, the then Liberal-National coalition opposition undertook to quarantine defence spending from any cuts. That was widely understood in the broad community, and I have got to say it was understood in the defence community, to mean the amount of money that was given to Defence in the 1995-96 budget would not be cut. That is actually not what happened, and if you read the fine print it was not what they promised to do.

In fact, what occurred was that the 1996-97 budget, the first Howard-Costello budget, cut defence spending by a half of one per cent—a $50 million cut in real terms was made in that budget. What the government really meant to tell the people of Australia at that time was that they would not cut the forward estimate of defence spending; they would not keep defence spending at the level it had been in 1995-96—that is what they were not going to do—in spite of the interpretation that the public put on it.

Over the course of the last two years that has been bandied around by the spin doctors. Finally, after the budget this year, the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) put out a press release that made it very clear that the Howard government had spent exactly the same amount of money on defence since it came to office as the Labor government was intending to do. And that is true. It needs to be understood as a matter of fact that the total outlays on defence are no different under both the Labor government and the coalition government.

It also needs to be put straight on the record that in the 13 budgets during Labor's period in office, contrary to a popular belief that there was some wind back in defence spending, the opposite is the case. Over that period there was a very substantial increase in real terms. If you look at those 13 budgets, you will find that in five of those budgets there was what is referred to as zero real growth. That is, the Defence budget was actually increased in dollar terms but increased to match the rising costs that Defence had to meet. I avoid reference to the CPI because Defence has its own calculation for adjustments, but in five of those budgets there was actually an increase to ensure that Defence maintained the real spending value of its dollar. On four occasions there was a cut and on four occasions there was an increase. If you look over the period, there was a substantial increase.

I too was disappointed at the reluctance of the Department of Defence to provide detailed advice on actual dollars and to give the committee its confidence. It was like extracting teeth at those hearings we had with people from Defence, seeking to get from them their best advice on what they believed was required for the defence of Australia. It really was like extracting teeth. I can understand their reluctance, the way the system works, as it were. We do not have parliamentary committees that operate in the same sense as American congressional or senate committees and we have an executive style of government.

But I thought it was a golden opportunity missed by Defence to use that forum to explain what they regarded as the necessary resources to take us into the 21st century. They should have known, if they did not, that there was a genuine sense of goodwill on the part of members of the committee to look at this matter properly and responsibly and in a bipartisan way to try to raise the debate within this parliament and in the community.

Having said all that, as shadow minister I cannot resist the opportunity to make a few points about the situation as it has unfolded in the last two years. A series of shortcomings and shortages and, in my view, poor decisions have been taken during the last couple of years. Some of those are more glaring than others. Some of them excite the journalists more than others. But you would have to put at the top of the lists in most of the categories the circumstance that developed last year where the Land Command was instructed to cut $16 million from its ammunition allocation to our defence forces. As a result of that, we had units all around the country, including in Darwin, in Townsville, right through Queensland and in the southern states, that did not have any allocation of particular types of ammunition—a zero allocation. It was across a wide range of armaments: small arms as well as artillery, armour—the full range of army weaponry.

We had units which in the previous year were not able to train people to be proficient on weapons in the 1996-97 financial year being told that they would not have any ammunition at all. So they would go for two years without training people on weapons. It is a disgrace that that should be so. The fact that it is so has been acknowledged in Senate estimates hearings. In those hearings the Department of Defence people said the government set about overcoming that problem not by rearranging the money to fix the problem at its source but by using our war stocks for training purposes. So during the last year we have run down our war stocks just so that basic proficiency training on a series of weapons could be achieved in our units across the country. That is a deplorable situation. With an election looming, I doubt that we will have another set of Senate estimates, but I am still waiting to see what the wash-up of all of that is.

But worse than the ammunition shortage is the shortage of people. In 1996, when we lost office, there were 58,000 permanent uniform people—air force, navy and army combined. I can recall the attacks from members of the Liberal and National parties about what a terrible thing it was that we had reduced Australia's defence forces down to 58,000 people. That was seen as a very low level for which we were criticised up hill and down dale by the conservatives. What did they do when they got into office? In the last two years, they have taken that 58,000 and reduced it to 54,000. What are they going to do in the next two years? If they get the opportunity, the Howard government are going to reduce that 54,000 to about 49,000.

Two years ago we were lambasted because 58,000 was far too small a force to defend Australia, and today we find a government that intends to take it to 49,000. If 58,000 was not enough to do the job two years ago, I am yet to hear the reasoning from anyone on the government benches as to how 49,000 is going to do the trick. They really have been caught hoisted on their own petard. I can assure you that their argument two years ago is going to come back and haunt them chronically in the next couple of months as we lead into an election.

One of the other things that needs to be recognised is that their answer to this funding dilemma has been a defence efficiency review and now the defence reform program—the DRP. One of the things that I have watched with some interest out of that is the proposals for base closures. Everywhere there has been an argument about base closures, the minister or the local member—who invariably is a government member—ends up saying, `No, this base isn't going to close.' That is fine, except that, as I go around the countryside, the list of bases that were identified by the DER as up for closure just gets ticked off—`No, that one is not going to be closed and the next one is not going to be closed'—but the minister still goes around talking about the money he is saving by closing the bases and the extra money he is going to have to spend on other things because the bases have been sold. You can have it one way or the other, but you cannot have both. You cannot actually say, `We're not going to sell the bases,' and then the next day say, `This is where we are going to spend the money from the sale.' Make up your mind: have one or the other.

All of this has produced a chronic morale problem in the services, and I do not say that in a partisan sense although, I guess, there is a partisan overtone to it. I have said in this House on a number of occasions that the morale in the Australian defence forces is chronically low—to the point where I think it injures the capacity of the services to do the job. I get worried when I talk to people of all ranks and of varying years of service—going right through to people who have had 20-plus years in the services—who say that the morale in the services today is the worst they have ever known it. That is a major issue that needs to be confronted. There are a whole lot of reasons for that. I do not have time to touch on them here, but I will do my best to touch on them between now and the election.

I want to make a quick comment about submarines, Anzac frigates and JORN. There have been problems with those. I was interested to listen to the comments of the member for Groom. I think he put a very modulated and responsible view of that. I would simply say that, in each of those cases, I think we will acquire—and in many ways have already acquired—very important assets for the defence of Australia. It is a bit of a sport to knock these things. It does not matter who is in government or who is in opposition, everyone tends to play that sport. I just provide this word of caution: if we want to establish a degree of self-reliance and we want to establish an Australian domestic industry capable of producing that self-reliance for us, you do not do it by knocking what are leading edge technologies.

Yes, there are problems with JORN. One of the reasons for that is that we are inventing a new technology. If you talk to people who are involved in this science in the United States, they will tell you that what we have here in Australia is better than what they have. This country is leading the world. When you are inventing a new technology—not changing someone else's or buying it off the shelf—there are set-backs and there are leaps and bounds. What we have done with the submarines is outstanding. Many of the things that have been written in the press about that are factually untrue, and it concerns me that both defence ministers, but particularly the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop), do not combat those. She fuels the fire with the sorts of comments she made about `rust buckets', `floating tubs' and `floating targets'. Those sorts of comments from ministers in positions of responsibility are unhelpful.

The final thing I would like to mention very quickly is the expenditure bulge. One thing we all have to know out of this debate—and it does not matter who is in government—is that somewhere between 2005 and 2015 this country will have a major defence bill to face. The sooner this parliament starts debating it, understanding it and addressing it and the sooner the community understands it, the better that will be for the nation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to correct the record of the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis). He is condemned by his own words in so much that he said right at the outset that this government followed the same forward estimates as presented by the last Labor government. I will restate that: we have, dollar for dollar, provided the same money as was put in the forward estimates by the Labor government. There is no disputing that.

speech.para: Having that amount of dollars that the Labor government was about to allocate to defence, he has said that there have been ammunition shortages and cases where units have gone without live firing practices, et cetera. That is not denied. I would like to know what he anticipated doing about it when they were in government when they allocated insufficient funds. That is on the back of savings which have been made within defence itself. There has been a rationalisation of defence. There has been an emphasis on putting soldiers, airmen and sailors back at what was commonly known as the sharp end.

It is one thing to say we have 56,000 soldiers one day and 49,000 a few years later, but it is all about capability. There is absolutely no point running 13 players onto a football team if half of them are lame. All 13 of them have to be fit, have to be well trained and have to be working as a cohesive team if they are to have any opportunity of winning. When in government, the Labor Party seemed to be of the impression that, if you have soldiers in uniform, that was good enough for the defence of Australia. It simply is not true.

The member for Brisbane also spoke about morale. I would like to take you back to when I was in the defence forces under a Labor government. I was a trainer. I was a platoon commander in depot company at the infantry centre. We had soldiers there who came to us to be trained as young infantry men after 11 weeks of recruit training. I would have three M60 machine guns between a section of 10 men to train them. Three between 10 just does not go. Those machine guns did not work. Soldiers would be charged for having what is known as `unauthorised discharges' when machine guns went off when they were not supposed to without explanation. The reason they did so was because the parts were worn. There was not sufficient funding in defence at the time, even at that lowest level. Forget about the major defence procurement programs; we are talking about the level at which lives are actually saved.

The main thrust of my speech tonight will be about the safety of our soldiers, our airmen and our women in the services. If we do not put sufficient funding into defence, we put at risk the lives of those people who have put their lives on the line for Australia. I would really appreciate it, if the member for Brisbane is going back to his office, if he listened to what I have to say. I am not saying that you are running out of the chamber, Arch; I know full well you are not. But go and have a listen. The fact is that by your own words, having said what you put into the forward estimates, you have already condemned yourself. You never left enough money in Defence; you never put enough money in Defence for each of the 13 years you were in government; and in the out years that are still to come, you never allocated enough.

talk.start.para: —Our year of lowest spending was higher than any year of your spending.
—Order!
—Okay, let us get to the facts.
—And the honourable member for Longman will direct his remarks through the chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, that is not a problem. In 1987, just before I left the army, the last exercise I attended was Exercise Diamond Dollar. I managed to get your attention for a couple of minutes, Arch. The fact is that this exercise, the largest defence exercise for the year for Australia, ground to a halt, with troops sitting next to their tracks. We had no air hours; no track time. And who should come in? Ros Kelly, Ms Whiteboard herself. She flew in to see an exercise that was not happening.

speech.para: The member for Brisbane talks about morale. I will tell you what destroys the morale of Defence Force personnel: when they do not feel they have anybody behind them, supporting them. It is not about how much they get paid. This is not a job; this is a lifestyle. This is a commitment that these people have—and that is what has made our defence forces great over many decades. But when they go on an exercise, they are away from their families, doing it tough, training so that they can defend our country. Then they are told, `It is half-time, so sit on your backsides and do nothing. The government has no money.' That destroys morale.

I got out of the army at a time when officers of my rank and majors were leaving the army in the greatest numbers ever; in epidemic proportions. The previous Labor government did nothing about it. The member for Brisbane talks about outlays. In this report, one of the recommendations is that there should be some form of long-term commitment, a five-year commitment, to defence so that personnel can have some certainty.

The fact is that Defence would get spending and outlays for one year and then be told—this is before forward estimates came into play—what it would be given the next year. It would then do its budgetary figures on that. It would plan its training, its maintenance, its personnel matters and its acquisitions.

But the problem is that, in all the years Labor was in government, not once did it exceed what it said it would put out. Its financial guidance for Defence in its first year was minus 1.7 per cent. Australia has just gone through a hell of a lot of heartache, and that has been because of a two per cent restriction of our expenditure in general. Defence went through a 1.7 per cent restriction on what it had been told it would receive compared with what it had received in its first year; 1.6 per cent in its second year; 4.2 per cent in its third year; 4.1 per cent in its fourth; 0.5 in the fifth; and one per cent, two per cent and one per cent for the remaining years.

Finally, when the then government decided that it was not going to waste any more money on defence, it then actually met its commitments. It cut defence spending in 1993-94 and retained its commitment; it cut defence spending in 1994-95, 1995-96, 1996-97 and met its commitments.

This government retained defence spending in a period when we had a $10 billion black hole to fix. I am a very strong advocate for an increase in Australia's defence budget; it must increase. If it does not, we are putting at risk the safety of every soldier, sailor and airman who trains for the defence of our country.

I turn now to the role of the public. The public come to me and say, `You've taken our guns away; we can't defend Australia.' Those days are well and truly gone. If those members of the public are serious about defending Australia, they should demand of the Labor Party or the Liberal-National Party—or any other party—that they increase defence spending and that they retain their commitments to Defence so that personnel can have some certainty in the out years.

This report recommends that there be certainty for a period of five years. It is no good saying to Defence, `This is what you're going to get over the next five years,' and then not delivering. Let us put it in very stark terms. In 1986, the government of the day made a decision to purchase the first lot of Black Hawk helicopters—14, I believe. As part of that, Defence was then told what the defence expenditure was to be in the out years. For that, Defence had to allocate money for the training of pilots, the training of the crew on the ground, maintenance and spare parts. It is well documented that the spare parts for the Black Hawk were never available.

What I am alluding to here is that, if we do not supply certainty to Defence, we put at risk the lives of the people whom we depend upon when our lives are at risk. If you get a new piece of equipment, you are told that it will cost you, say, $50 million to maintain the equipment, to have an adequate standard of training and to ensure that the spare parts are there. You build that into the estimates that the government of the day provides you, only to have it ripped away because the money is not actually given to you. So who loses out? I will tell you who loses out: it is the bloke who is out there who has to man the piece of weaponry, the ship, the aircraft, or whatever else it happens to be, because he does not have the air time, or whatever is required, to maintain the standard he needs to have.

That is a responsibility that politicians have to bear upon their shoulders. We must take some responsibility for what happened with the Black Hawk helicopter disaster. Also, we must ensure that this style of exercise, which is there to defend Australia, is able to be maintained through proper defence spending.

The member for Brisbane also alluded to the fact that Defence let itself down during this particular report, and I believe that is 100 per cent correct. It seems that Defence has some reason whereby it has to protect the ability of individuals to deal with the funds they have. For goodness sake, can't we admit for once that Defence does not have enough money, that this country needs more money to be put into Defence? Can't we convince the population that this is money well spent?

When we do not spend the money that is needed, we find that morale collapses and that trained personnel that have cost hundreds of thousands of dollars to get to a proficiency level leave the defence forces. When that happens, it puts the burden back onto the taxpayer to start to repopulate defence. That is a slow process, an expensive process and one that we can ill-afford. It is also important that we maintain a credible Defence Force because, if we are ever in the unfortunate position to be attacked or required to go to the defence of our nation offshore, we are going to need the assistance of our allies. If we are not able to train with them in such a way that we are relevant, then they will simply forget all about us in times of training, and we can be assured that that will flow through to times of greater need. We have to be a relevant force in this Pacific region. We have to be able to interact with other defence forces, and to do that we must maintain a defence budget which is credible.

The opposition made no bones about it: they cut defence spending overall because we were not able to maintain a credible force with a high morale, with people being able to use weapons efficiently and in a sufficient number of times to ensure that their levels of proficiency were maintained. This did not happen in 1997 or 1998. This has been happening for 15 years and perhaps even longer. We do need to upgrade defence. We do need to have a bipartisan position on this. We need to get away from squabbling. We need to say to the defence chiefs, `Regardless of who is in government, you are going to have a real increase in your defence spending of at least 1.5 to 2.5 per cent each year,' and we cannot afford to renege on that because we do so at our own great peril.

The defence forces of Australia are well renowned for their great attitude. These people are the ones that put their lives on the line. We as parliamentarians owe it to them to ensure that they have the resources, the ammunition, the training time and the spare parts so that their commitment can be fully realised. If we do not do that, then we are letting down our defence forces in time of peace. The old adage that you are what you train and what you do in the training paddock you take onto the field is every bit as applicable, I am sure, when it comes to defence.

I had a warrant officer once tell me—one of my first company sergeant majors—that during training for Vietnam they did not have blank firing attachments. This is a piece of equipment that allows a self-loading rifle to fire every time you squeeze the trigger. When initiating ambushes in training, he was forced to recock the rifle as though it were a bolt action. When he got into his first ambush in Vietnam, he did what he did in training. He fired his first round, he then recocked the rifle and fired another round and recocked it. His section commander gave him a clip over the ear at the end of it and said, `What the hell do you think you were doing?' The man simply did what he had been doing in training.

There are lessons in this for all of us. If we are going to ensure that our Defence Force maintains the high standard and the high level of attitude and commitment that it has, and the recognition that it has had around the world for being one of the best trained armies in the world, we are not going to be able to singularly rely upon those people's commitment. The rest of Australia must show its commitment by saying that our defence forces need considerable funds; that the $10 billion that is currently allocated is insufficient. We must ensure that the planners within Defence have the certainty to know that, from one year to another, they can rely on the money that has to come in to produce that same high level of training. That will maintain morale; that will maintain the standard of training that will take us into the next century.

Finally, I would like to comment quickly on the area of major procurements, because there are two time frames which are important to Defence. They have a five-year plan for force structure development. This is really maintaining the established capacity, whether it is replacing the M113 APC with some new piece of equipment or replacing the SLR with the Steyr, which was done in my time. Replacement programs for known obsolescence. The funding that we have in Defence is built into that, but there is also the strategic force development over 10 years where we have to look out and say, `What capabilities is Australia going to need to meet our defence forces' requirements?'

It is not good enough for politicians to simply say that we have put more money in than the previous government or the previous year. As the member for Brisbane and the member for Groom (Mr Taylor) have said, we have some major capital equipment programs coming up over the next 15 years. They must be dealt with separately over and above the operating expenses that Defence have. I commend this report to the House. I hope that all parties take up the recommendations in it; that for the best interests of this nation we maintain a bipartisan approach to defence in the future; that we stop political point scoring and looking to the past; that we look to the future with credibility, with enthusiasm and with the best interests of Australia in our hearts.

talk.start.para: —I have pleasure in addressing the report To have and to hold: Strategies to strengthen marriage and relationships prepared by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I would formally like to thank my fellow members of the committee, in particular, Kevin Andrews and Rob McClelland, for their time and dedication. In the following few minutes I would like to speak to five of the recommendations. In total, there were 55 recommendations made in the report. They highlight the main direction of the report towards providing greater education and counselling services and placing greater emphasis on their value for couples entering a marriage relationship. This is a complex and diverse issue where no one cause or factor can be attributed as the most significant or important reason for a marriage breakdown.

speech.para: The government has supported marriage and family life through its family services program for the past four decades and continues this concern and support as highlighted by the following recommendations. The committee recommended a national strategy to strengthen marital relationships through programs of preventive education; that family relationships service programs clearly recognise in their objectives the funding mechanisms of the programs for prevention; that the emphasis on marital relationships remain the focus of marriage and relationships education programs; marriage and relationship education relate to the three life transition events—namely, marriage, the birth of the first child and separation or repartnering. The committee also concludes that the system of funding the marriage and relationships education program reveals major inequities and recommends that it be rectified as a matter of urgency.

The development of marriage education in Australia has evolved as a convergence of educational, psychological and behavioural ideas. These ideas include emerging concepts of adult education, the notion that relationship skills can be learned, an understanding of some of the processes occurring in relationships and the theory that life involves a number of stages or transitions that people generally go through.

The development of pre- and post-marital education programs stems from different theories of psychological and behavioural studies. In an early work of marriage enrichment in the US in 1983, Diana Garland identified major approaches to supporting the marriage programs. Firstly, in essence, these theories emphasise teaching skills that couples can use to develop awareness of their patterns of interactions and to modify these patterns with changes in one another and their environment. Secondly, they emphasise the skill of being able to communicate with a partner with acceptance and understanding, to recognise feelings and motivations and to be able to express them clearly. Thirdly, they address the basic principles of learning as a consequence of positive and negative reinforcement. Finally, in a `church based' approach, Garland highlighted the importance of learning to satisfy basic needs, which should continue to grow by developing creativity and unused potential.

In Australia, most programs offered by marriage and family agencies tend to have been developed from a combination of Garland's four categories, but with less emphasis being placed on the final `church based' theory. The majority of Australia's marriage and relationship educational services target couples before marriage due to the philosophy of prevention that has been taken to be the most effective measure for reducing marriage and relationship breakdowns.

A fundamental core of marriage education is the understanding of the transitions that couples experience in their lives—namely, living together, marriage, having children and the maturation of the children. All these transitions represent periods of change characterised by specific tasks and challenges. Research demonstrates that couples experience more difficulties and are more vulnerable to the development of stress during these critical periods. Coupled with this is the importance of understanding differing family backgrounds. Increasingly, it is recognised that different attitudes, ideas and behavioural patterns that were developed within the couple's respective families are brought into the relationship and can serve as the source of further difficulties.

It is this awareness of marriage and relationships that has brought the committee to endorse its first five recommendations. Statistically, Australia has a 43 per cent divorce rate, with 52,500 couples divorcing in 1996. The central focus, therefore, of any marriage and relationship education scheme is towards prevention and, as such, targets premarital couples.

Acknowledging and supporting the ongoing and, indeed, the increasing need for marriage and relationship education programs, the committee also analysed the distribution of Commonwealth funding available for the maintenance of such schemes. It found that Commonwealth funding per participant ranged from a low of $7.80 to a high of $1,048.33. This variation in funding was found unacceptable. Similarly, the Commonwealth funding to agencies per course hour was revealed to range from $23 to $900. It is the committee's view that the system of funding is grossly inadequate and fundamentally flawed and that a new transparent and service delivery based funding scheme for marriage and relationships education should be implemented forthwith.

The issue of relationships and marriage in Australia is a serious one which potentially has the capacity to weaken Australia's healthy family unit, values and security. The recommendations made in this report are well founded and directed, and I strongly recommend their implementation.
