talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to report that I was at the Filipino multipurpose centre at Rooty Hill in my electorate to celebrate 100 years of independence of the Republic of the Philippines. I was very pleased to be joined by John Aquilina, the New South Wales Minister for Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Premier on Youth Affairs; the Mayor of Blacktown; Councillor Charlie Lowes; my state parliamentary colleague Jim Anderson, the member for Saint Marys; the present member for Londonderry; and the member for Greenway, Frank Mossfield, and his wife. It was really great to join in those particular celebrations. I notice the Chairman of the Philippines-Australian Parliamentary Friendship Group is in the House and I am sure he would join me in expressing our best wishes to all Filipinos.
—Hear, hear!

—I draw the House's attention to a speech the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) gave at the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre on Wednesday, 10 June. In particular, on page 3 of that speech, he said:

speech.para: When the Government came to office, the onshore application rate was increasing. The number of Protection Visa applications had increased from around 500 per annum in the 1980s to around 11,000 per annum. Many of these applications are from nationals of countries where there is little or no persecution—

And he cited the Philippines as one of the culprits. If Filipinos in my electorate are guilty, I believe that they are really victims more than guilty parties. The people that I really believe the minister should have targeted are what I describe as unscrupulous migration agents, who either get these people to sign blank forms and submit them, knowing that they have no chance of success, or solicitors who act as business migration agents and even unofficial migration agents. They know full well when they ask for not hundreds of dollars but several thousands of dollars to be handed over that these applica tions have no chance of success. The point I want to make is: what is the minister doing about this most unscrupulous practice? Indeed, I am really concerned that he is about to abolish what limited supervision we have by way of a board and replace it with self-regulation.

I stress that the Filipinos are so desperate to settle in this country that if it is suggested to them that they pay over several thousand dollars and that this will lead them to being able to stay, they are more than happy to do it. I believe that they are being fleeced. This brings no credit on anyone. I call on the minister for immigration to give us the figures on these applications and how many of them are being submitted by migration agents as opposed to individuals.

When people come to my office, like every other member, I do not charge them one dollar. I would like to think that all members would do as I or my staff do in relation to these matters, which is to be brutally frank and honest with people about the stringent requirements for protected visa status. I am always very reluctant to submit applications that I believe have little chance of success. But we always tell them. The thing that really sticks in my craw is that once these agents have the money, they refer them to federal members of this House in order to pursue it once the inevitable rejection has come through. It is time that Philip cleaned up the agents rather than getting stuck into Filipinos.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr Speaker, for your consideration. I want to address a group of Australian heroes this evening. I want to tell a very sombre and tragic story of a family in Parramatta whose home backs onto one of the little creeks and tributaries that flow into the Parramatta River in North Rocks. On Good Friday this year, as you may recall, there was a tremendous deluge around Sydney. The creeks were flooded well beyond anything that might be typical or normal. Two sons of the Hale family went down playing in the backyard as the creek swelled up. The youngest son, Ryan Hale, fell into the creek. He was 11 years old. His older brother tried to fish him out, but was unsuccessful. He saw him rushing down the creek. He raced up the hill and got the boys' father, who came down and, likewise, leapt into the creek to try to recover his son. But the force of the water was such that they lost sight of him. It was assumed, as it turned out, correctly, that he had perished.

speech.para: The whole community mobilised trying to find this boy, Ryan Hale. I recall being woken up early by my young son on the Sunday morning following Good Friday. I went down to Lake Parramatta at about 6 a.m. I found all the surrounds of Lake Parramatta were dotted with the orange overalls of the State Emergency Service. Many had been in the immediate search area for 36 hours without a break. I was put into one of the flat bottomed boats with the SES and the police, who were coordinating the search. We went up the river. It was one of the most poignant and distressing moments of my time as a parliamentarian to find the boys' father in a kayak paddling up and down the river looking for his son. Dozens of the SES were combing backwards and forwards along the river bank in the hope, one in a thousand, perhaps, that the boy might have been thrown unconscious out of the river and may be found somewhere in the bushes. As it turned out, they did recover young Ryan Hale's body later on that Sunday.

I was deeply impressed by the commitment and the quality of those SES volunteers. At the funeral the family requested, instead of flowers, donations to the SES, which purchased a flat bottomed boat, soon to be christened the Ryan H. The SES Parramatta is run by a bloke named Alex Zotos. He is a good member of the Australian Labor Party and a very committed Australian making a difference. He is supported by his two deputy controllers, George Dahmanjis and Steve Clarke, and a communications officer, Steve Anderson.

I was with Steve Anderson on the weekend when the Carlingford-Dundas Lions Club handed over a cheque for $3,000 to support the work of the SES. Steve was at a luncheon at Old Government House with us for the occasion. He was unshaven. He apologised because he had just returned from five days at Lake Macquarie following the tremendous storms that they had there towards the end of last week. The SES took over 800 calls around Lake Macquarie and over 2,000 around Maitland and Newcastle. Steve said to me that it was fortunate that he happened to have five days leave accrued when he got the call. I felt it was a tremendous example of unselfishness that he would spend those five days pulling trees out of the homes of people as far away as Lake Macquarie when so many others would, like myself, have taken the time off to rest and recuperate.

The Parramatta SES is in desperate need of resources. They have a yearly budget of $100,000. They get less than about $30,000 from government sources. I said to Alex Zotos, `Where do you get the rest?' He said, `Ross, you know me. I am a Greek. I scrounge, I borrow, I do whatever I have to.' He is a great Australian. I call on the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan), if possible, to help out with surplus water bottles, belts and backpacks. I call on all Australians to acknowledge the tremendous contribution of the men and women in the orange overalls.

talk.start.para: —On 10 September 1996, the member for Oxley, Pauline Hanson, infamously declared Australia was in danger of being swamped by Asians. Last Sunday she gave us a preview of her immigration policy with the call for compulsory English tests for all migrants. This is a key policy for One Nation. According to Mrs Hanson, no-one should migrate to Australia unless they speak English. This would involve a compulsory test with no exceptions. A migrant wanting to bring to Australia his or her elderly parents who do not speak English would not be able to do so. Overseas born spouses who do not speak English would be excluded. Refugee status would apparently be granted only to English speakers.

speech.para: These proposals have been rightly condemned. They are a disgraceful slur on the hundreds of thousands of Australians who have come here from overseas with little or no English and have gone on to help build this country's vibrant multicultural society. These proposals need to be considered in the historical context—the White Australia of old, for that is where Mrs Hanson would take this country. That is where Australia is perceived overseas to be going, especially in Asia where past perceptions of a racially exclusive Australia have been given new life.

Eighty-seven years ago, what became the Immigration Restriction Act of 1901 was the very first bill introduced into the Commonwealth Parliament. The legislative backbone of White Australia, that act did not explicitly discriminate against any race or group of people. Instead it established the `dictation test' through which `any person [who] when asked to do so by an [immigration] officer failed to write out at dictation and sign . . . a passage of fifty words in length in a European language' was deemed to be a prohibited migrant.

This was a test designed to be failed. Any European language could be used. If an Asian migrant could speak English, French or German, they could always be tested in Scottish Gaelic. It was a test designed to ensure that non-European migrants could not settle in Australia, and for nearly 60 years this administrative mechanism bolted Australia's doors against Asian migrants.

The language test proposed by Mrs Hanson might not be the dictation test of old, but the intention is exactly the same. What One Nation proposes is an ostensibly non-discriminatory test which would, in effect, be highly discriminatory—a test which, in the context of a much smaller migrant intake, would reduce Asian immigration to a trickle. It would be a new administrative wall to keep Asians out; it is as simple as that. One Nation wants to go back to White Australia, a country that no longer exists, a country to which we will never return.

All this would be laughable if it were not for the conspicuous failure of the Prime Minister, John Howard, to unambiguously confront Pauline Hanson by ensuring that all elements of the Liberal and National parties put One Nation last on their how-to-vote cards. Pauline Hanson would still be powerless were it not for John Howard's carefully coded messages of comfort and support to One Nation, and it is John Howard's failure that has so damaged regional perceptions of Australia over the past two years.

Our neighbours' worst suspicions about the White Australia of old, the country which applied the dictation test so rigorously, have been revived, to the detriment of our engagement with Asia. Australia has been pilloried in the regional press. The Hong Kong Standard has warned of the rise of One Nation, confirming fears that Australia is `headed back to its much maligned White Australia policy'. The South China Morning Post has highlighted the dangers of Australia returning to `institutionalised restraints and bigotry'. The Bangkok Post has accused John Howard of tolerating a `white supremacist'.

This is what is being said about Australia in the region where our future security and prosperity lies. Pauline Hanson and John Howard have undone 30 years of painstaking work to bury regional perceptions of White Australia, and worse may follow. Even with a half Senate election, we face the likelihood of the Senate being held hostage for the next six years by One Nation. Nor will John Howard rule out trying to govern with One Nation's support in the House of Representatives, with all the trade-offs that would involve in respect of immigration policy, indigenous affairs and, indeed, the core values of our multicultural society.

Honourable members would do well to note the recent editorial in the Singapore Straits Times which, after referring to John Howard's `indecent eagerness to bestow respectability' on Mrs Hanson, concludes:

If Mr Howard prefers the politics of opportunism . . . that is his privilege. But he should be under no illusion regarding the reaction of Australia's neighbours or the price that the Australian economy might have to pay.
The Prime Minister's colleagues would do well to reflect upon this.

talk.start.para: —I would like to draw to the attention of the House the plight of some elderly and vulnerable women in my electorate who, with others in Sydney, are the victims of some dubious practices by Vasey Homes. Recently four courageous residents of the Vasey Housing Village in Lane Cove, all war veterans or the wives of war veterans, came to see me with a desperate plea for help. The residents' concerns ranged from vote rigging to unconscionable conduct, including intimidation by Vasey management.

speech.para: Vasey Housing Association was established by Mrs Jessie Vasey many years ago to provide low-cost housing for ageing war widows and ex-servicewomen. Over the years the association has maintained the aims and objectives of Mrs Vasey by providing housing complexes around Australia, including six villages for 300 women in Sydney at Lane Cove, Waitara, Hunters Hill, Epping, Concord and Maroubra. Naturally enough, the residents are amongst the most elderly and frail in our community, with the ages of my local residents ranging from 79 to 92 years of age.

How did Jessie Vasey's vision become an organisation that holds dodgy secret ballots, breaks written agreements and feels that it can walk all over these defenceless women? Up until 19 February of this year, when a new budget was put to residents for a vote, Lane Cove Vasey was a peaceful and serene place in which to live. However, this new budget changed peoples lives by recommending a massive increase in maintenance costs for pensioners.

Previously all votes were taken by a show of hands. On this occasion the association held a so-called secret ballot. It was a secret ballot where residents were encouraged to put their names and addresses on the ballot papers. It was a secret ballot with no scrutineers. It was a secret ballot where ballot papers were immediately destroyed. It was a secret ballot where most of the residents challenged the shady result. In fact, in a similar vote held at Waitara there were more votes recorded than there were residents in the village, and that did not include eight residents who were absent at the time of voting.

Residents at Lane Cove rightfully challenged the result on two grounds: firstly, the ballot was clearly rigged and the result was highly suspect; secondly, the ballot breached the deed of occupancy which most residents signed when they entered the village. In clause 7.3 of the deed I have, it is clear that the maintenance fees cannot be increased by more than 20 per cent of the half yearly increase in the age pension, which is around $8. Residents are also paying entrance fees of up to $50,000 and share in the care and maintenance of the property. So a 44 per cent hike in the half-yearly fees from around $950 to around $1,400 is a clear breach of agreement between Vasey and these pensioners.

I do not know how much the directors of Vasey are earning, but I do know that hitting a war pensioner for an extra $840 a year is an unconscionable con job. What makes it worse is Vasey's sleazy attempt to cover up this nightmare. Vasey has used late night phone calls and visits to the homes of the more hesitant widows to try to intimidate them into signing new agreements that allow Vasey to increase fees at will. Some residents have signed up; others are defiant. However, Vasey is still sending notices to all residents demanding immediate payment at the new outrageous rates.

Obviously these pensioners fear that they will lose their homes. Some have received frightening letters from the chairman of Vasey threatening to cut support services if the new fees are not paid. The Aged Care Rights Service, the Department of Fair Trading and the Legal Aid Commission are all involved. The Governor of New South Wales, who is the patron of Vasey, has given an unsatisfactory standard response. Meanwhile, Vasey is treating the dispute resolution process with contempt.

Recently, management called in some residents to a disputes committee hearing. Management set the agenda, management set the charter and management nominated the representative residents. One of those nominated was an 83-year-old woman who was recently discharged from hospital after suffering a heart attack due to the stress of all these events.

These women are scared, but they are also great survivors. Many have lived through the Depression and tough times. They are vulnerable pensioners who have made huge sacrifices for others. We cannot let Vasey management get away with this deceitful activity, and I join these wonderful women in their battle to save not only their home but also the dignity of the vision of Jessie Vasey. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I wish to raise the workplace situation of three workers in my electorate who are front-line victims of John Howard's regressive industrial relations system. These workers are three ordinary Geelong blokes who gained employment in a new high technology malting plant owned and operated by a firm called Doosan Malting. They are all highly skilled workers who welcomed the opportunity to work in a modern plant in their local community close to their families. As I speak in this parliament tonight, the three workers maintain a picket line outside Doosan Malting in defence of their jobs, their wages and their conditions of employment.

speech.para: All workers, in a couple of hours time, face John Howard's Workplace Relations Act, which seeks to strip them of their award conditions. It is timely to reflect on the situation of the Doosan workers and what is in store for others in the Geelong work force as the clock runs past midnight. For these workers, John Howard's promise that they would be no worse off and that their award conditions would be preserved has proved to be one big lie. Many workers are of the view that a promise made is one that ought to be kept, but as far as this Prime Minister and this government are concerned the workers of Australia know that they have been comprehensively betrayed.

When these workers were employed, they went through an extensive interview process and medical tests. They received job offers from the company and they were told that their conditions of employment would be given to them later. On the first day of their employment, they were instructed to sign a trainee agreement with an out of town company called Goulburn Murray Group Training. Although employed as trainees, some workers undertook the supervision and training of casual employees hired at the malting plant while never receiving any of the normal training afforded other workers categorised as trainees and employed by local Geelong group trainers.

Some seven months after being employed, and after numerous requests of management to reach agreement on their conditions of employment, they finally sighted an employment agreement prepared by Doosan. This offered a flat rate of $15 per hour, a seven-day roster and no overtime or leave loading. In addition, these trainee workers, who had received no training from Goulburn Murray Group Training, were being called on to do call-ins in the middle of the night, with no supervision, for two hours pay and no rest breaks at all. After attempting to negotiate for better conditions, the company offered the workers individual contracts. They offered them John Howard's workplace agreements. Some of the workers concerned called upon their union to be their bargaining unit in negotiations and have been sacked for their trouble.

The simple facts of the matter are these: the workers concerned want no more than to work with dignity for a fair day's pay. They have been employed under questionable procedures and conditions and, where they have insisted on their legal right to bargain collectively and to be represented by their union, they have certainly paid a heavy price. This is the reality of John Howard's industrial relations promised land. The workers of Geelong have rallied to support them, and they have received strong guidance and support from their unions and the Geelong Trades Hall Council. My call tonight is to all workers in Geelong to support this picket. It is not a picket that has received great publicity in the national media, it is not a picket of the size of the MUA picket on the Melbourne waterfront, but it is a symbolic picket and one which represents much to Geelong workers.

As the clock runs past midnight tonight, the Howard government wants to strip away the award conditions of many workers. I am indebted to the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) for listing some of those awards that are being stripped away: for example, the obligation to notify employees and consult on the introduction of technological or workplace change; the requirement for discussions to take place prior to redundancies; employees not to be given notice of termination while on authorised leave; the requirement to provide employees with a statement of employment on termination; provision that a termination of employment shall not be harsh, unjust or unreasonable; provision in relation to sexual or racial harassment; the requirement to provide a first aid kit—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Before I call the honourable member for Lilley, I would like to introduce two young ladies to the House, Ms Renee Conroy and Ms Belinda Brooks, who are students of high schools in the electorate of the honourable member for Lilley.

—I am pleased to have with me in Canberra this week two students from my electorate of Lilley in Brisbane, Renee Conroy from Aspley State High School and Belinda Brooks from Hendra Secondary College. Renee and Belinda were selected by their respective high schools for their interest and ability in government studies. I would also like to express my thanks to Ansett Australia for providing air tickets to the girls for their visit to Canberra.

speech.para: Whilst performing work experience in my office, the girls have had the opportunity to study at first-hand the workings of parliament. They have also written a combined speech on the problems of youth of today which I will now read to the House:

The youth of today are facing many problems such as drugs, alcohol, unemployment, youth suicide and abuse. All of these problems can be helped if more information was made available to the youth of today. If the youth of today had a voice in government, a lot of problems could be heard and understood.

There are a lot of pressures that are placed on youth today. One of the many pressures of being a youth is succeeding in the schooling life. Pressures such as passing subjects and receiving a good OP result are placed upon youths at a very young age. One major influence that affects the development of youths are peers and peer pressure. Peer pressure is probably the most damaging and destructive way for a youth to develop. Drugs, stealing, alcohol and many other issues are some times faced in a peer group. The youths in today's society are often subject to pressures of being popular and accepted by their peers. This is often done by the use of drugs and alcohol.

Many young people are unaware of the dangers of consuming drugs and alcohol, and the result is sometimes harmful or even deadly to the teenager. What youth need is more education about the harmful effects of consuming drugs and alcohol. This could be done through schools. If there were frequent and continual education in every grade from year eight through to year twelve, then youth might be more responsible and learn to avoid drugs and alcohol. Counselling for teenagers should be considered within schools. This will enable teenagers to talk about alcohol and drug problems with a professional, who can help them overcome their addictions and deal with peer group pressures.

In today's society, youth are expected to attend school. In the hope of getting a job, the youths need an educational background in any chosen field. In the future, youths will have to face unemployment, because there is going to be an advancement in technology and computers. This advancement will replace jobs. This unemployment level will bring about more underage drinking, stealing and the use of drugs. More pressures will be placed on youth to get jobs, which will be unobtainable because of the unemployment levels.

Employment is a major concern for teenagers. Finding a part-time or full-time job while studying is difficult for today's youth. Teenagers have to overcome many problems in order to find jobs that suit them. Many teenagers who do not work or have only had a small amount of work experience often find it difficult to find a job after they leave school because of this lack of experience.

This problem may be reduced if schools provide work experience for all students in a particular grade level, so that they can obtain skills that will make them employable after they leave school. Apprenticeships should also be more widely available to many teenagers.

Youth suicide is not only a concern to the teenager who committed suicide but also the teenager's friends, family and the general public. Suicide is the second most common cause of death among Australians aged between fifteen and twenty-four. This is a major problem to society, and more should be done to help Australia's troubled youths. If there were more places for depressed or stressed youth to go to get help and talk about their problems, then maybe we could prevent some of them committing suicide. If there is more information about youth suicide provided to the public, then people may be able to detect early signs of suicidal behaviour. Also, counselling should be set up in schools so students can seek guidance and support.

Having a youth voice in Parliament could overcome some of the up-coming problems that young people face. Having politicians listen to what youth go through and what pressures they might be under, may help the youth of today realise that people listen and that they can help.
Renee's and Belinda's comments provide us with some very important thoughts to consider.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to take up a few points made by the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) last night about parliamentary debate. He said this in the adjournment debate:

speech.para: There is a gulf between those of us who sit in this chamber and the way we conduct our affairs and the attitudes, the customs and the behaviour of the Australians whom we are meant to represent.

If you visit any workplace, any home, any gathering of ordinary Australians, any club or any sporting organisation in this country, you will find language which is direct, blunt and, if need be, punishing. This is a defining characteristic of the Australian ethos. The mateship ethos in this country has always led to direct talking, disagreement and, if need be, debate and votes and disputation. It is the Australian way of doing things.

I do not think that in the current climate of the new type of politics we should be falling for the argument that this should be a chamber without debate. To listen to the member for Parramatta and his colleague the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), it is almost as though they want to turn this into some type of cathedral where we all find some higher force that leads to us linking hands, chanting and singing and all walking around agreeing with each other. That is not a parliament. A parliament has debate, and debate is healthy for democracy. The good thing about the things that are fired in this chamber is that they are words—not bullets, not things that physically harm people, but words which are meant for the contest of ideas and persuasion in a parliamentary system.

Let us not respond to some of the reaction we get from the media and perhaps some of the things that the Hansonites say by losing sight of the fact that this is a chamber made for debate and, if need be, disagreement. In the best of Australian traditions, let us make it direct and blunt and engage in Australian straight talking. It is not a cathedral. We will never find the higher force here. You might find it in other places but not right here, and not all us will share it even if you can find it in some other place.

I think there are challenges for our parliamentary system, challenges we need to take seriously. We talk about the information revolution and we talk about a post-industrial society, but we run the parliament on horse and buggy principles. We run the parliament in a fashion that really has been overtaken by many forms of communication. I worry a great deal that the sovereignty and public attention of our democracy in many ways has moved to the airwaves, not so much parliamentary debate. If you asked the average Australian what they thought about the system of democracy, where they find their connection, they would say it is on talkback radio or TV. We need to adapt to that, but in the process of adaption we do not need to lose sight of the fundamentals of the parliamentary system which are about debate.

Let us have a discussion about forms of direct democracy using new electronic superhighway technology. Let us have a talk about means by which we can better educate the public about our system of democracy, its responsibilities, its strengths and its flaws. Let us have a debate about accountability and participation in this chamber. But I am sick and tired of hearing people say that somehow we should be a chamber without debate. Let us never have that.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.

—I should respond briefly to the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). Yes, let us have real debate in this chamber; let us have real debate in this parliament. In fact, the member for Werriwa began a real debate inside the Labor Party when he raised the subject of a progressive expenditure tax, a kind of super GST. It is a real pity that this most interesting idea of the member for Werriwa has not been fully debated in this chamber and, indeed, inside the Labor Party, and it is a real pity that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and others on the frontbench of the Labor Party have not seen fit to pursue debate on this matter.

speech.para: I rise specifically to respond to the comments of the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton) and to refute the idea that this government has any sympathy for or any truck with any party appealing to racial prejudice or pandering to the fears, rather than the hopes, of the Australian people. I think it is important to pose the question: is the One Nation Party a genuine political party at all or is it just a get-rich-quick scheme for the benefit of the two Davids, Oldfield and Ettridge, who are now the part owners and major shareholders of One Nation Ltd?

As far as can be worked out, Pauline Hanson's One Nation Ltd has just three directors and five shareholders. Much the same can be said for Pauline Hanson's One Nation Members Inc. which was formerly the Pauline Hanson Support Movement. The question is: where is the actual political party that has the 25,000 members which Messrs Oldfield and Ettridge constantly speak of, although I have to say informed insiders say that the real figure is closer to 4,500? What is this mysterious entity to which all these people supposedly belong?

Yesterday, a resident of Manly knocked on the locked door of One Nation headquarters at Suite 2, Level 1, 15 The Corso, Manly. When the door was slightly opened, the caller said that she was interested in One Nation and she would like a membership form and a copy of the party's constitution. `No, we do not give those out,' boomed a male voice from the back of the office. A determined local member of parliament is not so easily put off, and I am pleased to say that I have finally tracked down a copy of the constitution of the party—not Pauline Hanson's One Nation Ltd, not Pauline Hanson One Nation Members Inc., but Pauline Hanson's One Nation as registered under the Queensland Electoral Act. I should point out that last week David Oldfield defended One Nation's corporate structure. He said:

The Liberal Party in NSW, for example, is an unincorporated association of members. It has no protection for its members for its debts. Its members have joint and several liability for the Party's debt. That's how the Liberal Party's structured.
Maybe their members should start asking about what they're doing running up bills because they're responsible for the money.

That is what David Oldfield said last week. Yet when one gets a copy of the constitution of Pauline Hanson's One Nation, as registered in Queensland—surprise, surprise!—the actual party is guess what: an unincorporated association of members. In that respect it is exactly like other parties, but it is quite unlike other parties in that this party has two classes of members. It has management committee members, of whom there are just three, who totally run everything to do with the party, and there are affiliate members who, as far as I can work out, have absolutely no rights whatsoever.

The member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) repeats over and over again, `We are all Australians and everyone has the same rights.' If that is what she really believes, why doesn't she practise what she preaches and allow equal rights inside One Nation? I should point out that the three people in charge as management committee members of Pauline Hanson's One Nation in Queensland have complete control over the $500,000 in taxpayers' money to which that party is entitled in the wake of the Queensland election and there is absolutely no democratic accountability whatsoever to stop those three blowing it all on a trip to Vanuatu. (Extension of time granted)

There is absolutely nothing at all to stop those three people blowing it all on a trip to Vanuatu to view David Ettridge's tax haven. The member for Oxley has often attacked multinational companies for using overseas tax havens, in effect to force the battlers of Australia to pay more than their fair share of tax. As the Treasurer (Mr Costello) pointed out in question time today, the National Director of One Nation, David Ettridge, set up his own company in Vanuatu, one of the world's most notorious tax havens, to launder money received through his fundraising activities.

This is bad enough, but he set that company up little more than a year after a bankruptcy order was made against him in the Federal Court in Sydney. Not only that but that order was secured by the Australian Taxation Office against David Ettridge on account of non-payment of $28,000 in taxes. I am not a lawyer, but it is my understanding that bankrupts must wait three years before becoming company directors, and I ask the ASC to investigate whether this company was set up not only to avoid tax but also to evade Australian bankruptcy laws. I call upon the ASC to do this because it seems that One Nation's leaders are avoiding tax while One Nation's followers are paying it. What was David Ettridge's reaction when he was confronted with this? The Australia/Israel Review, which I commend for its pursuit of these matters, stated:

Asked to comment on almost two years of litigation and adverse judgements to retrieve his unpaid taxes, Mr Ettridge initially told the Review that the Federal Court documents were forgeries and that he had never been declared a bankrupt.

When it was pointed out that the official documents were provided by the Federal Court, Mr Ettridge admitted that he had been declared bankrupt but had "then paid the amount owing and it was annulled. I was tardy in not dealing with the matter earlier. As far as I am concerned, it is as if it never happened".

That is David Ettridge. We must really pose the question: are the senior people in One Nation Ltd simply chronic and habitual liars? They are very good at bandying around accusations of lying. David Oldfield was all over the airwaves today accusing different former members of One Nation of lying. Last week he accused me of lying over David Ettridge's 12.5 per cent commission on all One Nation donations. That was what he was saying last week, but what was David Oldfield saying in January? In January when David Oldfield was first confronted with reports of Mr Ettridge's commission deal— and I quote from the Advertiser of 9 January—he `confirmed Mr Ettridge received a commission of around 12.5 per cent'. Then he thought again, it seems, and said:
"I don't think it's as high as 12.5 per cent, but it might be," he said. "It might be for the first million (of funds raised)."

Was David Oldfield lying then? Was he just befuddled? Did he have an attack of the Max Willises? Or is he lying now? I think the Australian people should be the judge, but I think the conclusion they are rapidly coming to is that the One Nation Party is one gigantic con. I seek leave to table the following documents: One Nation's corporate structure, the constitution of Pauline Hanson's One Nation and documents relating to the bankruptcy of Mr David Ettridge.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 31 March 1998:

question.para: What items of indigenous cultural property have been repatriated to Australia since 1988 and (a) when, (b) whence and (c) in what circumstances was each repatriated.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Since 1988 the Commonwealth has been involved in a number of returns of Aboriginal human remains from overseas collecting institutions. These include:

Yagan: The skull of Yagan was returned to Australia on 2 Sep 1997 following its exhumation from the Everton Cemetery in Liverpool in the UK. It was reclaimed by a delegation of Nyoongar community representatives following a campaign lasting many years. The return was funded jointly by the Western Australian Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

Recent returns by representatives of the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre (TAC). The TAC has been active for many years in seeking the return to Australia of both Tasmanian human remains and artefacts held in overseas collections. The TAC claims a unique authority to represent Tasmanian Aboriginal people's interests in relation to cultural property, and has pursued its program often independently of ATSIC involvement or assistance.

Because it has avoided relying on ATSIC resources the TAC does not report to the Commonwealth on the outcomes of its endeavors, and ATSIC is unable therefore to provide details on the material it has repatriated independently.

The remains of Tambo: Tambo was taken as a circus attraction to the United States, where he died last century. His embalmed remains were discovered in the premises of a funeral director in the United States and offered up for repatriation in 1993. The remains were collected by Palm Island community representatives funded and assisted by the ATSIC State Office in Brisbane.

Edinburgh University: There were two releases of remains from Edinburgh University in 1991. The first consisted of eleven Tasmanian crania which, although initially offered up to the Commonwealth were accepted by a TAC delegation and returned in July 1991. The TAC delegation was partially funded by ATSIC.

In October 1991 a delegation approved by the ATSIC Board of Commissioners, and funded by ATSIC, collected 299 mainland remains, mostly crania. The collection was transferred to the custody of the National Museum of Australia (NMA), and some remains have been collected by Aboriginal community representatives. Because of poor provenancing, and a failure by the States to assist communities within their jurisdictions, a large part of the collection remains in the custody of the NMA.
ATSIC has funded research projects to further provenence the collection. We have been informed that the University of Edinburgh wishes to make a further release of post-cranial remains.

Kelvingrove Museum, Glasgow: October 1990, 3 human remains from Mt Morgan in Queensland were accompanied back to Australia by an officer of the Foundation for Aboriginal and Islander Research Action (FAIRA), and a traditional owner for the area, William Toby. The return was funded by ATSIC and the remains were dealt with by the Aboriginal community.

Pitt Rivers Museum, Oxford: Representatives of the TAC and FAIRA retrieved the crania of 5 individuals, and a preserved sub-incised penis, from the Pitt Rivers Museum in June 1990. The visit was funded by ATSIC. This return was simultaneous with a return of material from Bradford and Peterborough museums.

Bradford and Peterborough: In June 1990 2 crania from the Bradford and Peterborough museums were accepted by an Aboriginal officer of the Australian Public Service to be couriered to Australia. The officer was met by representatives of the TAC and FAIRA who assumed responsibility for distributing the remains upon returning to Australia.
Dublin, Royal College of Surgeons: In 1990 the preserved head of a Tasmanian man was collected from Dublin by the TAC.

answer.para: 1 Signature is the act whereby a State expresses its consent to the text of a treaty but not necessarily its consent to be bound by its provisions. Once a State has signed a treaty it is not obliged to ratify it. However, the Australian government's policy is not to sign a treaty without the intention to ratify it at a later date. Ratification is confirmation of signature and signifies the intention to be bound by the provisions of a treaty. Accession is a single act whereby a State expresses its consent to be bound, instead of signature followed by ratification. Accession is only used in the case of multilateral agreements, usually when the agreement has been previously signed by other States. Acceptance of a convention once it has been signed has the same effect at ratification.
